PREFACE
         This code of the City of Drumright, as supplemented, contains
ordinances up to and including ordinance 350, passed December 9, 2024.
Ordinances of the City adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of
this code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith.
Consult the City office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision
of the code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
                     American Legal Publishing
                     Cincinnati, Ohio
ORDINANCES PENDING CODIFICATION
Listed ordinances have been passed, but they have not been incorporated into
the code and they may not show the original ordinances in their entirety.
Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions concerning
the ordinances listed.
TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATION
CHAPTER 1
OFFICIAL CITY CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Territorial Jurisdiction
1-1-5: Ordinances In Effect In Outlying City Property
1-1-6: Code Alterations
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon the adoption by the board of commissioners, this city code is hereby
declared to be and shall hereafter constitute the official city code of
Drumright. This city code of ordinances shall be known and cited as the
DRUMRIGHT CITY CODE and is hereby published by authority of the board of
commissioners and shall be supplemented to incorporate the most recent
legislation of the city as provided in section
1-1-3 of this chapter. Any reference to the number of any section contained
herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same number, its
appropriate chapter and title heading, and to the general penalty clause
relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is made to
this city code by title in any legal documents. (2002 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
The city code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received
without further proof in all courts and in administrative tribunals of this
state as the ordinances of the city of general and permanent effect, except the
excluded ordinances enumerated in section
1-2-1 of this title. (2002 Code)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending the city code shall set forth the title, chapter and
section number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall
constitute sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to
the amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this city code. All such
amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to the
codifiers, and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in
its proper place in each copy of this city code. Each such replacement page
shall be properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of
the city code. (2002 Code)
1-1-4: TERRITORIAL JURISDICTION:
The provisions of this code shall be applicable and effective within the
corporate boundaries of the city, and all other territory over which the city
is granted police power, or other power, by virtue of the laws and constitution
of the state of Oklahoma. (1980 Code § 10-9)
1-1-5: ORDINANCES IN EFFECT IN OUTLYING CITY PROPERTY:
   A.   All ordinances of the city now in effect within the city are hereby
extended to all real property belonging to, or under the control of, the city
outside the corporate limits of the city, and shall be in full effect therein,
insofar as they are applicable.
   B.   All ordinances of the city which shall go into effect in the future
shall also apply to, and be in full effect within, the boundaries of all said
outlying real property, insofar as they may be applicable.
   C.   Any words in any ordinance indicating that the effect of an ordinance
provision is limited to the corporate limits of the city shall be deemed to
mean and include also the said outlying real property belonging to, or under
the control of, the city, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. (1980
Code § 10-10)
1-1-6: CODE ALTERATIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or
deletions any part or portion of this code, or to insert or delete pages, or
portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such code in any manner whatsoever
which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby; provided,
that supplementation of this code by authorized persons shall be permitted.
(2002 Code)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal Of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Public Ways And Public Utility Ordinances
1-2-3: Conflicting Provisions; City Code Prevails
1-2-4: Court Proceedings
1-2-5: Separability Clause
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the city passed prior to the adoption of this city
code are hereby repealed, except such as are included in this city code or are
by necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject to the saving
clauses contained in the following sections), and excluding the following
ordinances which are not hereby repealed: tax levy ordinances; appropriation
ordinances; ordinances relating to boundaries and annexations; franchise
ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights to persons or
corporations; contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the execution of a
contract or the issuance of warrants; salary ordinances; ordinances
establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other public places;
improvement ordinances; bond ordinances; ordinances relating to elections;
ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate by or from the
city; and all special ordinances. (2002 Code)
1-2-2: PUBLIC WAYS AND PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroad crossings with streets and other public ways,
or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public utilities shall
be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this city code or by virtue of the
preceding section, excepting as the city code may contain provisions for such
matters, in which case, this city code shall be considered as amending such
ordinance or ordinances in respect to such provisions only. (2002 Code)
1-2-3: CONFLICTING PROVISIONS; CITY CODE PREVAILS:
Whenever there is a conflict between the express provisions of this code, and
the provisions of national and state codes herein adopted by reference, the
express provisions of this code shall prevail over those adopted by reference.
(1980 Code § 10-8)
1-2-4: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
   A.   Prior Acts: No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a
former ordinance whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as
to any offense committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done,
any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or
claim arising under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any
such offense or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or
punishment so incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new
ordinance takes effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform
to the ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as
practicable. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment may be mitigated by any
provision of a new ordinance, such provision may be, by consent of the party
affected, applied to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes
effect.
   B.   Extend To All Repeals: This section shall extend to all repeals, either
by express words or implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making
any new provisions upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
   C.   Current Pending Actions: Nothing contained in this chapter shall be
construed as abating any action now pending under or by virtue of any general
ordinance of the city herein repealed, and the provisions of all general
ordinances contained in this code shall be deemed to be continuing provisions
and not a new enactment of the same provisions; nor shall this chapter be
deemed as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering any penalty accrued or
to accrue, or as affecting the liability of any person, firm or corporation, or
as waiving any right of the city under any ordinance or provision thereof in
force at the time of the adoption of this city code. (2002 Code)
1-2-5: SEPARABILITY CLAUSE:
If a court of competent jurisdiction should hold one or more ordinance sections
or a part of an ordinance section of this code or of an ordinance passed
hereafter invalid, such holding shall not affect the remainder of the code or
ordinance nor the context in which such section, sections or part of a section
so held invalid may appear, except to the extent that an entire section or part
of a section may be inseparably connected in meaning and effect with the
section, sections or part of a section so held invalid. (1980 Code § 10-11)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Construction Of Words
1-3-2: Definitions, General
1-3-3: Catchlines
1-3-1: CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS:
   A.   Whenever any word in any section of this city code importing the plural
number is used in describing or referring to any matters, parties or persons,
any single matter, party or person shall be deemed to be included, although
distributive words may not have been used. When any subject matter, party or
person is referred to in this city code by words importing the singular number
only, or a particular gender, several matters, parties or persons and the
opposite gender and bodies corporate shall be deemed to be included; provided,
that these rules of construction shall not be applied to any section of this
city code which contains any express provision excluding such construction or
where the subject matter or context may be repugnant thereto.
   B.   The word "ordinance" contained in the ordinances of the city has been
changed in the content of this city code to "title", "chapter", "section" and/
or "subsection" or words of like import for organizational and clarification
purposes only. Such change to the city's ordinances is not meant to amend
passage and effective dates of such original ordinances. (2002 Code)
1-3-2: DEFINITIONS, GENERAL:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this code, they shall have
such meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meaning
repugnant thereto:
AGENT: A person acting on behalf of another with authority conferred, either
expressly or by implication.
BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS: The board of commissioners of the city of Drumright.
CLEET: Council on law enforcement and education training.
CITY: City of Drumright, counties of Creek and Payne, state of Oklahoma.
CODE: The city code of the city of Drumright.
COUNTY: The county or counties of Creek and/or Payne, state of Oklahoma.
EMPLOYEES: Whenever reference is made in this code to a city employee by title
only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the city of
Drumright".
FEE: A sum of money charged by the city for the carrying on of a business,
profession or occupation.
GENDER: A word importing either the masculine or feminine gender only shall
extend and be applied to the other gender and to persons.
LICENSE: The permission granted for the carrying on of a business, profession
or occupation.
MISDEMEANOR OR PUBLIC OFFENSE: Any violation or failure to comply with any of
the terms, conditions or requirements of any ordinance, or section or part
thereof, contained in this code.
NUISANCE: Anything offensive to the sensibilities of reasonable persons, or any
act or activity creating a hazard which threatens the health and welfare of
inhabitants of the city, or any activity which by its perpetuation can
reasonably be said to have a detrimental effect on the property of a person or
persons within the community.
OS: Oklahoma Statutes.
OCCUPANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who
occupies the whole or any part of such building or land whether alone or with
others.
OFFICERS: Whenever reference is made in this code to a city officer by title
only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the city of
Drumright".
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: As applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint
owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of a part of
such building or land.
PERSON: Every person, male or female, natural or artificial, and when
applicable, shall be held to be any firm, partnership, corporation or common
law trust.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Shall include every description of money, goods, chattels,
effects, evidence of rights in action and all written instruments by which any
pecuniary obligation, right or title to property is created, acknowledged,
transferred, increased, defeated, discharged or diminished and every right or
interest therein.
RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate
to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things direct to the consumer.
RIGHT OF WAY: The privilege of the immediate use of the roadway or other
property.
STATE: The state of Oklahoma.
STREET: Shall include alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards, public ways, public
squares, public places and sidewalks.
TENANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies
the whole or any part of such building or land, whether alone or with others.
WHOLESALER; WHOLESALE DEALER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be
understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things to
persons who purchase for the purpose of resale.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING: May include printing and any other mode of representing
words and letters, but when the written signature of any person is required by
law to any official or public writing or bond, it shall be in the proper
handwriting of such person, or in case such person is unable to write, by such
person's proper mark. (1980 Code §§ 10-1, 10-2; amd. 2002 Code)
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of the city code are intended as mere
catchwords to indicate the content of the section and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of such sections, nor be deemed to govern, limit, modify or
in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any
section hereof, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when
any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (2002
Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty
1-4-2: Application Of Provisions
1-4-3: Liability Of Officers
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY:
Any person adjudged guilty of the violation of any provisions of the revised
ordinances or code, and where the penalty is not specifically fixed for that
offense, shall, upon conviction, be fined in any amount not exceeding the sum
of five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus costs as provided in title 11 Oklahoma
Statutes annotated section 27-126 or any amendment thereto or imprisonment not
exceeding sixty (60) days or both the fine and imprisonment. Whenever necessary
for the proper enforcement of any chapter, article, section or subsection, each
day's violation of any of the terms or conditions thereof shall be deemed a
separate offense. (Ord. 236, 1-23-2003)
1-4-2: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   Application Of Penalty: The penalty provided in this chapter shall be
applicable to every section of this code the same as though it were a part of
each and every separate section.
   B.   Acts Punishable Under Different Sections: In all cases where the same
offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of
this code, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed, but not
more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same
offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or permit shall not be
considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced.
   C.   Breach Of Provisions: Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to
do any act constitutes a breach of any section or provision of this code and
there shall be no fine or penalty specifically declared for such breach, the
provisions of this chapter shall apply. (2002 Code)
1-4-3: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of
the board of commissioners to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or
employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the
duty. (2002 Code)
CHAPTER 5
BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 1
SECTION:
1-5-1: Elective Officers; Terms
1-5-2: Appointive Officers
1-5-3: Mayor And Vice Mayor
1-5-4: Qualifications Of Commissioners
1-5-5: Oath Of Office
1-5-6: Bonds
1-5-7: Compensation
1-5-8: Meetings
 
Notes
1 1. See also sections 5 through 20 of the city charter.
1-5-1: ELECTIVE OFFICERS; TERMS:
The elective officers of the city shall consist of a commissioner at large and
four (4) other commissioners, one commissioner to be elected from each of the
four (4) wards of the city; all for two (2) year overlapping terms. (1980 Code
§ 1-3)
1-5-2: APPOINTIVE OFFICERS:
   A.   Appointments By Commissioners: The appointive officers of the board of
commissioners shall be as follows:
City manager
City treasurer
   B.   Appointments By Manager: The city manager shall appoint and remove all
heads of departments and all subordinate officers and employees of the city
with the exception of those reserved by the city charter for the discretion of
the board of commissioners. (1980 Code § 1-5)
1-5-3: MAYOR AND VICE MAYOR:
   A.   Election From Members: The commission shall elect from among its
members a chairman and a vice chairman, who shall bear the official titles of
mayor and vice mayor, respectively, who shall serve until the expiration, of
their terms as commissioners.
   B.   Duties Of Mayor:
      1.   The mayor shall preside at meetings of the commission and shall
certify to the correct enrollment of all ordinances and resolutions passed by
it.
      2.   He shall be recognized as the head of the city government for all
ceremonial purposes and by the governor for purposes of military law.
      3.   He shall have no regular administrative duties except that he shall
sign all warrants, checks, other orders for the disbursements of money,
conveyances and such other written obligations of the city as the commission
may require.
   C.   Vice Mayor:
      1.   Duties: The vice mayor shall act as mayor during the absence or
disability of the mayor, and if a vacancy occurs, shall become mayor for the
completion of the unexpired term.
      2.   Vacancy In Office: If, by succession to the office of mayor or
otherwise, the office of vice mayor becomes vacant, the commission shall elect
another vice mayor. (1980 Code § 1-6)
1-5-4: QUALIFICATIONS OF COMMISSIONERS:
Each commissioner must be at least twenty five (25) years of age and a
qualified elector of the city, not in litigation with the city, nor in arrears
for city taxes when elected, and must have been for two (2) years preceding his
election, a bona fide resident and taxpayer of the city, or territory legally
annexed thereto, and in case of commissioners to be elected from the wards of
the city, each commissioner must at the time of his election, be an actual
resident in good faith, of the ward from which he is elected. (1980 Code § 1-7)
1-5-5: OATH OF OFFICE:
Every officer of the city, before entering upon the duties of his office, shall
take and subscribe to the oath or affirmation of office as prescribed by the
state constitution, and the laws of this state now or hereafter required of all
persons holding public office in this state. The oath shall be filed and kept
in the city clerk's office. (1980 Code § 1-8)
1-5-6: BONDS:
The city clerk, the city treasurer and commissioners, and such other officers
and employees as the commission by ordinance may designate, before entering
upon their duties, shall provide bonds for the faithful performance of their
respective duties, payable to the city, in such form and in such amounts as the
commission may prescribe by ordinance, with a surety company authorized to
operate within the state. The city shall pay the premiums on such bonds. (1980
Code § 1-9)
1-5-7: COMPENSATION:
The mayor and other commissioners shall each receive as their compensation, for
their services rendered the city, the sum of not to exceed one dollar ($1.00)
per year, plus reimbursement for their necessary and reasonable expenses
incurred in the service of the city. (1980 Code § 1-4)
1-5-8: MEETINGS:
   A.   Regular: Regular meetings of the board of commissioners of the city
shall be held on the second Monday of each month at seven o'clock (7:00) P.M.
in the city hall, unless a different time and place is so designated by the
board, and may be adjourned to subsequent dates and times as deemed necessary
by the mayor and board of commissioners. (Ord. 245, 12-7-2004)
   B.   Special: Special meetings may be called at any time by the mayor or by
any three (3) of the commissioners. (1980 Code § 1-2)
   C.   Open Meetings: Meetings of the board of commissioners shall be open to
the public, pursuant to 25 Oklahoma Statutes section 301 et seq. (2002 Code)
CHAPTER 6
CITY OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
SECTION:
1-6-1: Personnel Regulations And Policies
1-6-2: Employee Complaint; Informal Discussion
1-6-3: Grievance; Formal Presentation
1-6-4: Employee Fringe Benefits
1-6-5: Federal Old Age And Survivors Insurance
1-6-6: Employee Retirement System
1-6-7: Employee Deferred Compensation Plan
1-6-1: PERSONNEL REGULATIONS AND POLICIES:
The board of commissioners, by motion, resolution or ordinance, may regulate
the number and classes of officers and positions of employment in the various
departments, offices, and agencies of the city government, and may determine or
regulate the compensation to be paid to officers and employees. (1980 Code § 1-
70)
1-6-2: EMPLOYEE COMPLAINT; INFORMAL DISCUSSION:
   A.   Jurisdiction Of Immediate Supervisor: Whenever an employee feels he has
a complaint, it should be discussed fully with the immediate supervisor. The
supervisor will make every effort to dispose of the complaint in a fair and
equitable manner and in accordance with the established policy of the city, the
department, or the division. This should usually take no longer than three (3)
working days unless there are extenuating circumstances. (1980 Code § 1-70.1)
   B.   Disagreement With Supervisor Decision: An aggrieved employee who is
dissatisfied with the decision of the immediate supervisor as set out in
subsection A of this section should notify the supervisor of his desire to
contact and consult with the city manager on the complaint. The city manager
will give guidance to the supervisor and employee. The immediate supervisor may
attend this initial meeting; however, the employee may request a subsequent
meeting with the city manager without the supervisor in attendance. If the
informal discussion does not result in a satisfactory solution, the employee
may proceed as set out in subsection
1-6-3A of this chapter. (1980 Code § 1-70.1; amd. 2002 Code)
1-6-3: GRIEVANCE; FORMAL PRESENTATION:
   A.   Filing Formal Grievance:
      1.   Specify Grievance And Desired Remedy: The employee who has been
unsuccessful in resolving a grievance in an informal manner will specify the
grievance and the desired remedy in writing to his immediate supervisor. If the
grievance is in regard to a disciplinary matter (formal reprimand, suspension
and discharge), it must be filed as a formal grievance within three (3) working
days of written notification of such action. All other issues must be filed as
formal grievances within ten (10) calendar days after the employee becomes
aware of the issue.
      2.   Hearing By Division Head: (Optional; this step is used only when the
number of levels require it.) Failing a resolution of subsection A1 of this
section, the employee will submit the grievance in writing to the division head
within two (2) working days from the receipt of the decision. The division head
will schedule a hearing within two (2) working days. The employee will be at
the hearing. At this hearing, the employee will be able to present witnesses in
support of the grievance. The immediate supervisor must attend this meeting and
state the reasons for the earlier decision. The division head will give a
written decision on the hearing to all parties involved within two (2) working
days.
   B.   Submit Grievance To City Manager: Failing a resolution of subsection A
of this section, the aggrieved employee will submit the grievance in writing to
the city manager within two (2) working days from receipt of the prior step
decision. The city manager will schedule a hearing to be held within three (3)
working days. The employee shall be present at the hearing. The employee will
be able to present witnesses in support of the grievance. The immediate
supervisor and the division head, if applicable, must attend this hearing. The
city manager will give all parties involved a written decision on the hearing
within three (3) working days.
   C.   Personnel Board; Hearing: The personnel board shall consist of the city
attorney as chairman with two (2) citizens knowledgeable of personnel related
activities who shall be appointed by the mayor and ratified by the city
commission for an indefinite term. Failing a resolution of the previous step,
the aggrieved employee will submit the grievance in writing to the personnel
board within two (2) working days from receipt of the decision in subsection B
of this section. The personnel board will schedule a hearing to be held within
three (3) working days. The employee shall be present at the hearing. The
employee will be able to present witnesses in support of the grievance. The
immediate supervisor, the division head, and the city manager, if applicable,
must attend this hearing. The personnel board will give all parties involved a
written decision on the hearing within three (3) working days.
   D.   Mayor; Hearing: Failing a resolution as set out in subsection C of this
section, the aggrieved employee will, within two (2) working days of the
receipt of the prior step decision, make known to the mayor his desire for the
mayor to personally hear the grievance. The personnel board will forward all
pertinent information to the mayor and a meeting will be scheduled by the mayor
within five (5) working days of receipt of the documents. The employee, the
immediate supervisor, and the city manager must be present at the hearing. The
mayor may affirm, overrule, or modify prior decisions within three (3) working
days. The mayor's decision will be final and binding.
   E.   Compliance With Time Limits: All time limits should be met, unless the
time limits are extended for good cause in any step. The parties should be
notified in writing of the reasons for the delay within the time limits.
   F.   Pay-Benefit Policies: Grievances on pay matters are limited to
interpretations of pay practices under the pay-benefit policies. They may not
be filed with the purpose of changing or challenging such pay or benefits
policies.
   G.   Resolution Of Grievance: A grievance is resolved if the employee fails
to appeal within the time limits required at each step. Obviously, resolution
is achieved whenever mutual agreement has been reached.
   H.   Failure To Follow Procedure: Failure to follow this procedure,
including the proper sequence, may subject the employee to discipline. (1980
Code § 1-70.2)
1-6-4: EMPLOYEE FRINGE BENEFITS:
   A.   Paid Time Off And Extended Illness Accrual Bank: Paid time off and
extended illness accrual banks are hereby authorized as provided in the
employee handbook. (Ord. 291, 7-11-2011)
1-6-5: FEDERAL OLD AGE AND SURVIVORS INSURANCE:
   A.   Benefits: It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the
city to extend, at the earliest date, to the employees and officials thereof,
not excluded by law or this section, and whether employed in connection with a
governmental or proprietary function, the benefits of the system of federal old
age and survivors insurance as authorized by the federal social security act
and amendments thereto, including public law 734 – 81st congress. In pursuance
of this policy, and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be
required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (1980 Code § 1-
113)
   B.   Mayor Authorized To Execute Agreements: The mayor is hereby authorized
and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with
the state department of public welfare, as agent or agency, to secure coverage
of employees and officials as provided in subsection A of this section. (1980
Code § 1-114)
   C.   Withholdings From Salaries And Wages: Withholdings from salaries or
wages of employees and officials for the purpose provided in subsection A of
this section are hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times
as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and
shall be paid over to the state or federal agency designated by said laws or
regulations. (1980 Code § 1-115)
   D.   Appropriations For Employer's Contributions: There shall be
appropriated from available funds such amounts at such times as may be required
by applicable state or federal laws or regulations for employer's
contributions; which shall be paid over to the state or federal agency
designated by said laws or regulations. (1980 Code § 1-116)
   E.   Records And Reports: The city shall keep such records and make such
reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations.
(1980 Code § 1-117)
   F.   Person Covered Under Other Retirement Systems: There is hereby excluded
from this section any authority to make any agreement with respect to any
position or any employee or official now covered or authorized to be covered by
any other ordinance creating any retirement system for any employee or official
of the city. (1980 Code § 1-118)
   G.   Personnel On Fee Basis Excluded: There is hereby excluded from this
section any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position, or
any employee or official, compensation for whom is on a fee basis, elective
officials engaged in rendering "legislative" services (including the mayor and
commissioners), or any position, or any employee or official not authorized to
be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (1980 Code § 1-
119)
1-6-6: EMPLOYEE RETIREMENT SYSTEM:
There is hereby adopted by reference, as though set forth herein in its
entirety, an employee retirement system for the city. A copy of said retirement
system, and amending ordinances, shall be on file and available for inspection
in the office of the city clerk. (2002 Code; amd. Ord. 334, 11-12-2019; Ord.
339, 3-14-2022; Ord. 350, 12-9-2024)
1-6-7: EMPLOYEE DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN:
There is hereby adopted by reference, as though set forth herein in its
entirety, an employee deferred compensation plan for the city. A copy of said
employee deferred compensation plan, and amending ordinances, shall be on file
and be available for inspection in the office of the city clerk. (2002 Code)
ARTICLE A. CITY MANAGER 1
SECTION:
1-6A-1: Appointment; Term; Qualifications; Removal
1-6A-2: Acting City Manager
1-6A-3: Powers And Duties
1-6A-4: Purchases And Sales
1-6A-5: Interference With Appointments And Removals
1-6A-6: Conflict Of Interest
1-6A-7: Payment Of Claims Against The City
 
Notes
1 1. See also sections 21, 22 and 23 of the city charter.
1-6A-1: APPOINTMENT; TERM; QUALIFICATIONS; REMOVAL:
   A.   Appointment; Term; Qualifications:
      1.   There is hereby created the position of city manager.
      2.   The city manager shall be appointed for an indefinite term by the
board of commissioners.
      3.   The city manager shall be chosen solely on the basis of his
executive and administrative qualifications. At the time of his appointment, he
need not be a resident of the city or state; but, during his tenure of office,
he shall reside within the city.
   B.   Suspension Or Removal: The commission may suspend or remove the city
manager at any time when such suspension or removal has been confirmed by a
majority vote of the board of commissioners. (1980 Code § 1-10)
1-6A-2: ACTING CITY MANAGER:
If the city manager is to be absent from the city or is unable to perform his
duties on a temporary basis, he shall, by letter filed with the city clerk,
appoint an employee of the city to be the acting city manager until he returns
or is again able to perform the duties of the city manager. If the city
commission suspends the city manager or if there shall be a vacancy in the
office of the city manager, the city commission may appoint an acting city
manager to serve until the city manager's suspension is ended, or until the
vacancy in the office is filled by appointment of a city manager by the city
commission. The city commission may suspend or remove an acting city manager at
any legally called city commission meeting, where the item is properly listed
on the agenda, by a majority vote of all of its members. (Ord. 273, 6-14-2010)
1-6A-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The city manager shall be chief executive officer and head of the
administrative branch of the city government. He shall execute the laws and
administer the government of the city, and shall be responsible therefor to the
commission. He shall:
   A.   Appoint and, when necessary for the good of the service, remove all
heads of administrative departments and other administrative officers and
employees of the city except as otherwise provided in the city charter and
except as he or the commission by ordinance may authorize the head of a
department, an officer or agency to appoint and remove subordinates in such
department, office or agency, subject to such merit system regulations as the
commission may ordain.
   B.   Supervise and control, directly or indirectly, all administrative
departments, agencies, officers, and employees.
   C.   Prepare a budget annually and submit it to the commission for, and be
responsible for, the administration of the budget after it goes into effect,
and recommend to the board of commissioners any changes in the budget which he
deems desirable and in the best interests of the city.
   D.   Submit to the mayor and board of commissioners, a report as of the end
of the fiscal year on the finances and administrative activities of the city
for the preceding year.
   E.   Keep the board of commissioners advised of the financial condition and
future needs of the city, and make such recommendations as may seem to him
desirable.
   F.   Perform such other duties as the city charter may prescribe and such
duties as the commission may prescribe. (1980 Code § 1-12)
1-6A-4: PURCHASES AND SALES:
   A.   Contract Or Authorization: The city manager, subject to any other
regulations which the board of commissioners may prescribe, shall contract for
any purchase, or issue purchase authorizations for all materials, supplies and
equipment for the offices, departments and agencies of the city government.
Every such contract or purchase exceeding ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00)
shall require the prior approval of the city commission. The city manager may
also transfer to or between offices, departments and agencies any item or items
purchased by any other office, department or agency of the city.
   B.   Bidding Opportunity: Before the purchase of, or contract for, any
materials, supplies or equipment exceeding ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00)
there shall be an opportunity to bid on the item or items by all known vendors
and by advertisement in a newspaper of general circulation. Items that are the
subject of a state purchasing contract or a county purchasing contract, if made
available to municipalities of the same price, may be exempted from the bidding
requirement.
   C.   Change In City Management: Upon a future change in city management, the
purchasing authority of the city manager shall revert back to a limit of three
thousand dollars ($3,000.00) and purchases exceeding three thousand dollars
($3,000.00) must be purchased through the competitive bid system after approval
of the city commission. If, however, a situation arises that threatens the
delivery of gas or water to the city or portions of the city, the purchasing
authority of the city manager shall be a limit of five thousand dollars
($5,000.00) so he can make necessary repairs to ensure gas and water can be
delivered to residents. If the city manager makes repairs to the gas or water
utilities in accordance with this subsection, he will notify each city
commissioner via e-mail, phone, or personal delivery of a message within twenty
four (24) hours of taking action. Further, he will provide each commissioner
with copies of the invoices outlining the specific repairs within twenty four
(24) hours of receiving them. (Ord. 295, 1-14-2013)
1-6A-5: INTERFERENCE WITH APPOINTMENTS AND REMOVALS:
Neither the commission, the mayor, nor any of its other members may direct or
request the appointment of any person to, or his removal from, office or
employment by the city manager where he has been given such authority to
appoint or remove. Except for the purpose of inquiry, the board and its members
shall deal with the administrative service solely through the city manager; and
neither the commission nor any member thereof may give orders on administrative
matters to any subordinate of the city manager either publicly or privately.
(1980 Code § 1-14)
1-6A-6: CONFLICT OF INTEREST 1 :
   A.   Restrictions: The city manager shall not sell or barter anything to the
city or to a contractor to be supplied to the city; or make any contract with
the city; or purchase anything from the city other than those things which the
city offers generally to the public (as for example, utility services), and
then only on the same terms as are offered to the public. Any such officer
violating this section, upon conviction thereof, shall thereby forfeit his
office. Any violation of this section, with the knowledge expressed or implied,
of the person or corporation contracting with the city, shall render the
contract voidable by the commission. This subsection shall not apply in cases
in which the city acquires property by condemnation.
   B.   Further Regulations: The commission by ordinance or personnel rules may
further regulate conflict of interest and ethics of officers and employees of
the city. (1980 Code § 1-15)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  1-8-3 of this title.
1-6A-7: PAYMENT OF CLAIMS AGAINST THE CITY:
   A.   The city manager shall be responsible for the review and approval for
payment of claims for all expenditures of the city. All claims shall be made on
purchase orders properly issued by the accounts payable clerk which shall
certify that the amount is within the approved budget for the account charged.
All claims must be approved by the encumbering officer and the department
director initiating the purchase or expenditure prior to approval by the city
manager. The city manager is authorized to designate an officer of the city to
review and approve claims on his behalf. A listing of all payments approved by
the city manager within the past month shall be provided to the city commission
at its regular monthly meetings.
   B.   All payments shall be made on regular schedules which shall assure
payment of bills in a timely manner. Exceptions to regular payment schedules
must be authorized by the city manager or his designee. (Ord. 255, 9-8-2008)
ARTICLE B. CITY CLERK 1
SECTION:
1-6B-1: Appointment; General Duties
1-6B-2: Bond Required
1-6B-3: Powers And Duties
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 27 of the city charter.
1-6B-1: APPOINTMENT; GENERAL DUTIES:
There shall be a city clerk who shall be an officer of the city appointed by
the city manager for an indefinite term, and shall perform all clerical duties
pertaining to the city. He shall issue all licenses and keep an accurate
account of all receipts and expenditures of the city. He shall attend all
meetings of the board of commissioners and record their proceedings; keep the
proper books of accounts appertaining to the office; record all ordinances of
the city in a book to be provided for that purpose, and shall prepare and
present to the board of commissioners each month a full and detailed report of
the receipts and expenditures of the city for the month, and perform all other
duties as may be required of him by law or by ordinances of the city, or board
of commissioners. (1980 Code § 1-16)
1-6B-2: BOND REQUIRED:
The city clerk shall execute a surety bond to the city for the faithful
performance of his duties as such city clerk in a sum determined by motion or
resolution by the board of commissioners. The premium on said bond shall be
paid by the city. (1980 Code § 1-21)
1-6B-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   Custodian Of Seal And Documents: The city clerk shall keep and preserve
in his office the corporate seal of the city, all records, public papers and
documents of the city, not belonging to any other officer.
   B.   Financial Duties: The clerk shall receive monies collected by other
city personnel and give his receipt for the same. He shall pay all monies
collected and paid in over to the city treasurer, who shall credit same to the
proper account and give his receipt for the same. (1980 Code § 1-17)
   C.   Claims; Register:
      1.   The city clerk shall keep a register of claims and bills filed with
him against the city, which claims shall be numbered consecutively,
corresponding with the number of such claims upon the register.
      2.   The register herein mentioned shall always include in one column the
number of the claims and in separate columns, respectively, the name of the
claimant, date of filing, amount thereof, for what purpose, on what fund, date
paid, the number of the warrant by which it is paid. It shall be the duty of
the city clerk to keep all claims against one fund separate and apart from
other funds and each such claim shall show upon its face the particular fund to
which the same is by law chargeable. The city clerk shall draw all warrants
against the city treasurer, but no warrant shall be drawn until first
authorized by the board of commissioners. (1980 Code § 1-18)
   D.   Issue Licenses: The city clerk shall, until otherwise prescribed by the
city manager or the board of commissioners, issue all licenses provided by
ordinance when the proper application has been filed and the fees have been
paid to him. He shall receive all water rents due the city from consumers of
water based on readings furnished by the water superintendent and issue receipt
for the same and shall after such collection, pay said monies to the city
treasurer, taking duplicate receipts therefor. The clerk shall receive all
monies due the city from any source, when not otherwise provided expressly by
law or ordinance and in each and every case shall issue his receipt for the
same, showing the date received, the person from whom received, the amount
received and the purpose of the same. (1980 Code § 1-19)
   E.   Monthly Report; Other Duties: The clerk shall make monthly reports to
the board of commissioners at the first meeting in each month and at such times
as it may require, giving in detail a statement of all receipts and
expenditures of money belonging to the city and shall perform such other duties
as may be required by the city manager or the board of commissioners. (1980
Code § 1-20)
ARTICLE C. CITY TREASURER 1
SECTION:
1-6C-1: Appointment; General Duties
1-6C-2: Bond Required
1-6C-3: Deposit Of Funds
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 28 of the city charter.
1-6C-1: APPOINTMENT; GENERAL DUTIES:
   A.   Appointment; Term: There shall be a city treasurer who shall be an
officer of the city appointed by the commission for an indefinite term who
shall perform in general all duties required by law and the ordinances of the
city. (1980 Code § 1-22)
   B.   City Clerk Shall Serve As Treasurer: The city clerk shall also serve as
city treasurer for the city of Drumright and the office shall be known as city
clerk-treasurer. The clerk-treasurer shall perform all duties required of the
treasurer by the state statutes, the city charter and this code. (Ord. 258, 1-
12-2009)
   C.   Duties:
      1.   It shall be the duty of the city treasurer to receive and safely
keep all monies of the city which may come into his hands and disburse the same
upon the order and warrants of the mayor and city clerk, legally drawn; to keep
in suitable books full and accurate accounts of all monies received and
disbursed by him on behalf of the city, specifying the time of disbursement,
from whom received, to whom paid, and on what received and disbursed; to keep a
separate account of each fund or appropriation and the debits and credits
belonging thereto; deliver to every person paying money into the city treasury
a receipt therefor, and a duplicate therefor to the city clerk, specifying the
date of payment and on what account paid.
      2.   The treasurer shall keep all notes, bonds and other evidence of
indebtedness belonging to the city, except those given by himself, which shall
be kept by the city clerk, and such notes, bonds and other evidence of
indebtedness belonging to the city shall always be subject to the order of the
board of commissioners.
      3.   The city treasurer shall pay no money out of the treasury except
upon the order or warrant signed by the mayor and countersigned by the city
clerk. (1980 Code § 1-22)
1-6C-2: BOND REQUIRED:
The city treasurer shall execute a good and sufficient surety bond to the city
in such sum as may be determined by motion or resolution of the board of
commissioners, for the faithful performance of duties as such treasurer, said
bond to be approved by the board of commissioners. Premium on said bond shall
be paid by the city. (1980 Code § 1-24)
1-6C-3: DEPOSIT OF FUNDS:
   A.   Surety Bond Required For Bank: The treasurer shall deposit all city
funds in a bank situated in the city. Before making any deposit, the treasurer
shall take from each such bank a surety bond of some surety company authorized
by the proper authorities of the state of Oklahoma to do business in said
state, in a sum equal to the largest approximate amount that may be deposited
in each respectively at any one time; said surety bond to be uniform and
prescribed by the city attorney. Provided that in lieu of said surety bond or
in addition thereto, security may be taken consisting of United States bonds,
state bonds or warrants, or other bonds or warrants issued by a municipality
under authority of and in compliance with the statutes of Oklahoma; provided,
that all said warrants shall have been issued pursuant to a legal
appropriation. All surety bonds taken under the provisions of this section
shall bear the approval of the city attorney and the board of commissioners and
all securities accepted in lieu of surety bonds shall bear the approval of the
board of commissioners. The securities and surety bond shall bear the approval
of the board of commissioners. The securities and surety bond shall be at all
times in the custody and under the control of the city treasurer. The condition
of said bond shall be that such deposit shall be promptly paid on a check or
draft of the treasurer of such city and the bondsmen of such treasurer shall
not be liable for such deposit. Such banks shall, on the first Monday of each
month file with the city clerk a statement of the amount of money on hand
belonging to the city at the close of business each day during the previous
month and the amount of interest accrued thereon to such date.
   B.   Banks Outside City: Nothing in this section shall be construed to
prohibit the city treasurer from depositing funds of the city in banks outside
the city when authorized by the commission and when such banks shall place with
the city treasurer the same class of security and amount as hereinbefore
provided. It is hereby made unlawful for any of the city funds to be deposited
in any bank in which the city treasurer or any member of the board of
commissioners shall be the owner of any stock or otherwise interested. All
securities or bonds accepted by the treasurer shall first be approved by the
commission. (1980 Code § 1-23)
ARTICLE D. CITY ATTORNEY 1
SECTION:
1-6D-1: Department Of Law; Appointment
1-6D-2: Member Of Bar Association
1-6D-3: Duties
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 24 of the city charter.
1-6D-1: DEPARTMENT OF LAW; APPOINTMENT:
There shall be a department of law, the head of which is the city attorney
appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term, and removable by the city
manager, following notice and opportunity for hearing before the city council.
The city attorney is an officer of the city, and has supervision and control of
the department of law. (1980 Code § 1-30; amd. 2002 Code)
1-6D-2: MEMBER OF BAR ASSOCIATION:
The city attorney shall be an active member in good standing of the Oklahoma
bar association. (1980 Code § 1-31)
1-6D-3: DUTIES:
   A.   The city attorney shall advise the city manager, board of
commissioners, and all other officers of the city upon legal questions
affecting the duties of their offices or the interests of the city as may from
time to time be referred to him.
   B.   He shall appear and prosecute any person charged with the violation of
any ordinance of the city on trial before the municipal court.
   C.   He shall represent the city in all actions or proceedings in all courts
wherein the city is a party or may be interested, and shall perform such other
professional services as may be required of him by law or by the appointing
authority. (1980 Code § 1-32)
CHAPTER 7
CITY DEPARTMENTS
ARTICLE A. POLICE DEPARTMENT 1
SECTION:
1-7A-1: Department Established; Appointment
1-7A-2: Duties Generally
1-7A-3: Chief Of Police
1-7A-4: Arrests
1-7A-5: Unclaimed Property
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 24 of the city charter.
1-7A-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENT:
There shall be a police department, the head of which is the chief of police
appointed for an indefinite term by the city manager. The chief of police is an
officer of the city and has supervision and control of the police department.
All policemen are officers of the city. (1980 Code § 1-25)
1-7A-2: DUTIES GENERALLY:
It is the duty of the police department to apprehend and arrest on view or on
warrant and bring to justice all violators of the ordinances of the city; to
suppress all riots, affrays and unlawful assemblies which may come to their
knowledge, and generally to keep the peace; to serve all warrants, writs,
executions, and other processes properly directed and delivered to them; to
apprehend and arrest persons violating federal or state law as provided by law,
and to turn them over to proper authorities; and in all respects to perform all
duties pertaining to the office of police officers. The police department has
charge of and operates the city jail. (1980 Code § 1-26)
1-7A-3: CHIEF OF POLICE:
   A.   Duties: The chief of police shall be the chief peace officer of the
city. He shall arrest offenders against any of the ordinances of the city, and
do general police duty in the city, and attend upon the municipal court. He
shall perform such other duties as may from time to time be required of him by
law or ordinance. (1980 Code § 1-27)
   B.   Bond: The commission may require the chief of police to execute a
surety bond to the city for the faithful performance of his duties. If
required, the bond shall be in a sum determined by motion or resolution by the
board of commissioners. If required, the premium shall be paid by the city.
(1980 Code § 1-29)
1-7A-4: ARRESTS:
The chief of police or any other police officer shall have power to make or
order an arrest, with proper processes, for any offense against the laws of the
state or of the city and without process when such offenses are committed in
his presence. (1980 Code § 1-28)
1-7A-5: UNCLAIMED PROPERTY:
   A.   Complete Record Required: All personal property which comes into the
possession of any police officer, which has been found or stolen or taken off
the person or out of the possession of any prisoner or person suspected of, or
charged with, being a criminal, and which is not known to belong to some person
laying claim thereto, shall be by the officer securing possession thereof,
delivered into the charge of the chief of police. The chief shall, in a
permanent record book kept for that purpose, make a record sufficient to
identify the property, with the date and circumstances of the receipt thereof,
the name of the person from whom it was taken and the place where it was found;
and the record shall also disclose the subsequent disposal thereof, giving the
date of sale, name and address of the purchaser, and the amount for which it
was sold. (1980 Code § 17-1)
   B.   Disposition Of Unclaimed Property: Any unclaimed personal property
other than animals, which remains in the possession of the chief of police,
unclaimed, or the ownership of which is not to him satisfactorily established,
for a period of ninety (90) days, shall be sold, and the proceeds of the sale
shall be paid over to the city clerk, who shall issue his receipt therefor and
deposit the same to the credit of the general fund of the city, except such
personal property as in the opinion of the mayor can be more advantageously
used by some department or office of the city government. Ten (10) days before
a sale of such unclaimed property, the chief of police shall sign and have
posted in a conspicuous place in the city clerk's office, where it will be
plainly visible to persons who visit that office, notice of the time, place and
manner of such sale and general description of the property to be sold.
Provided that, if in the opinion of the mayor, all or any portion of the
personal property may be more advantageously used in any city department or
office, he shall so instruct the chief of police in writing and the chief shall
thereupon deliver the personal property designated to that department or office
of city government and make a permanent record of its disposition. (1980 Code §
17-2; amd. 2002 Code)
   C.   Property Found By Private Person: Any personal property found by a
person other than a public official or employee, which is delivered to any
police officer for identification, if not claimed or identified within ninety
(90) days, shall within ten (10) additional days thereafter, if requested by
the finder, be returned to him, and a record of such disposal made thereof. If
the finder does not request return of the property to him within such
additional ten (10) days, then the chief of police shall sell the property as
if it had been found by a public official or employee or on instruction by the
mayor deliver it to some department or office of the city government for its
use. (1980 Code § 17-3; amd. 2002 Code)
   D.   Recovery By Owner: If any property is sold as herein provided, and the
owner thereof takes and recovers possession of same from the purchaser, the
amount paid therefor shall be returned to the purchaser, upon verified claim
being submitted and approved by the city commission. (1980 Code § 17-4)
ARTICLE B. FIRE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
1-7B-1: Department Established; Appointment
1-7B-2: Authority Of Chief Over Department, Equipment
1-7B-3: Duties And Responsibilities Of Chief
1-7B-4: Assistant Chief
1-7B-5: Police Powers Of Department
1-7B-6: Control Over Persons And Property
1-7B-7: Discipline
1-7B-8: Firefighters; Desired Qualifications
1-7B-9: Probation Period Of Employment
1-7B-10: Compensation
1-7B-11: Firefighters Pension And Retirement System
1-7B-12: Reports By Fire Chief
1-7B-13: Volunteer Firefighters
1-7B-14: Monthly Meetings
1-7B-15: Secretary
1-7B-16: Alarm Of Fire
1-7B-17: Police Officers Act As Fire Guard
1-7B-18: Vehicles And Pedestrians; Duty Upon Alarm Of Fire
1-7B-19: False Alarms; Prohibited Acts
1-7B-20: Penalty
1-7B-21: Fire Protection Fee Scale
1-7B-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENT:
   A.   Appointment: There shall be a Fire Department, the head of which is the
Chief of the Fire Department, or Fire Chief, appointed for an indefinite term
by the City Manager. The Chief of the Fire Department is an officer of the
City, and has supervision and control of the Fire Department. (1980 Code § 1-
33)
   B.   Terms Synonymous: In this article the terms "firefighter" and "firemen"
shall be interpreted as being synonymous and interchangeable. (1980 Code § 1-
52)
1-7B-2: AUTHORITY OF CHIEF OVER DEPARTMENT, EQUIPMENT:
The Fire Chief shall safeguard and securely keep all fire apparatus, hose, and
other appliances used by the Fire Department in extinguishing fires in the
City, and he shall account for all such property as may come into his hands
during his term of office. He shall have full authority over the Fire
Department whenever they are in active service and, in the absence of the
Chief, the duties devolving upon the Chief of the department shall be performed
by the Assistant Chief on duty. (1980 Code § 1-34)
1-7B-3: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF CHIEF:
   A.   The Chief shall be at the head of the department, subject to the laws
of the State of Oklahoma, ordinances of the City, and the rules and regulations
herein adopted.
   B.   The Chief shall be held responsible for the general condition and
efficient operation of the department, the training of members, and the
performance of all other duties imposed upon him.
   C.   The Chief may inspect or cause to be inspected by members of the
department, the fire hydrants, cisterns, and other sources of water supply at
least twice each year. The Water Department will assist in flushing operations.
   D.   The Chief shall maintain a library or file of publications on fire
prevention and fire protection, and shall make use of it to the best advantage
of all members.
   E.   The Chief shall make every effort to attend all fires and direct the
officers and members in the performance of their duties.
   F.   The Chief shall see that the citizens are kept informed on fire hazards
in the community and on the activities of the department.
   G.   The Chief shall see that each fire is carefully investigated to
determine its cause, and in the case of suspicion of incendiarism shall notify
proper authorities and secure and preserve all possible evidence for future use
in the case. (1980 Code § 1-35)
1-7B-4: ASSISTANT CHIEF:
In the absence of the chief, the assistant chief on duty shall command the
department and be held responsible therefor in all respects with the full
powers and responsibilities of the chief. (1980 Code § 1-36)
1-7B-5: POLICE POWERS OF DEPARTMENT:
The fire chief and assistant fire chiefs are hereby given all the authority of
police officers of the city so far as necessary in the exercise of their duty,
and are hereby authorized to make arrests for interference in the discharge of
the duties of their office, or for any interference with the operation of the
fire department. (1980 Code § 1-37)
1-7B-6: CONTROL OVER PERSONS AND PROPERTY:
The fire chief or assistant chief on duty shall have full power, control, and
command over all persons and property at fires, shall station the fire
apparatus, and see that all members of the fire department perform the duties
prescribed by ordinance and the rules of the department. He shall direct such
measures as he shall deem most advisable for the extinguishment of fires and
establish lines or zones as are needed; and every person who shall obstruct,
hinder, or resist him or any member of the department in the performance of
their duties shall be guilty of an offense. (1980 Code § 1-38)
1-7B-7: DISCIPLINE:
   A.   Enforcement: It is the duty of the chief of the fire department to
enforce such discipline in the fire department as prescribed by ordinance or as
may be contained in rules of conduct formulated by the fire chief with the
approval of the appropriate authorities of the city.
   B.   Standards For Imposing Penalties: The measuring out of penalties for
breach of duty, unauthorized absence, conduct detrimental to the morale and
effectiveness of the department, conduct reflecting on another employee of the
department or on the city or for violation of other rules as established by
subsection A of this section shall be by such standards as to protect the
interests of the fire department, to promote good discipline so that the morale
and effectiveness of the department, in whole or in part, will be best served,
and that the principle of fairness to the employee involved in the violation
will be preserved.
   C.   Suspension For Insubordination: The fire chief shall have the right,
and the obligation, to suspend instanter, with discharge or release from
employment intended, any firefighter, regular or volunteer, who is
insubordinate by reason of persistent or determined refusal to do as instructed
or requested, subject to the rights of review, if any, provided by this code.
This right and duty of immediate suspension of an employee by the fire chief
also shall apply in like degree to any firefighter who is charged by the fire
chief with theft, immoral conduct, wilfully destroying property of the city or
of another employee, fighting on city property or while in the performance of
duty as a firefighter or any conduct detrimental to the morals, discipline or
welfare of the fire department. (1980 Code § 1-39)
1-7B-8: FIREFIGHTERS; DESIRED QUALIFICATIONS:
Firefighters, regular or volunteer, shall be selected upon their ability to
meet the following requirements:
   A.   Knowledge of firefighting and prevention;
   B.   Knowledge of firefighting equipment;
   C.   Disposition to follow orders;
   D.   Capacity to learn; and
   E.   Potential as leaders of others. (1980 Code § 1-42)
1-7B-9: PROBATION PERIOD OF EMPLOYMENT:
All new members of the fire department, regular or volunteer, shall be on
probation for one year after their appointment. (1980 Code § 1-43)
1-7B-10: COMPENSATION:
The chief of the fire department and all members of the fire department shall
receive such compensation as may be provided by the board of commissioners.
(1980 Code § 1-44)
1-7B-11: FIREFIGHTERS PENSION AND RETIREMENT SYSTEM:
   A.   Compliance With State Law: The firefighters pension and retirement
system shall be operated in accordance with state law relating to said system
and pensions and other benefits shall be paid as provided by state law. (1980
Code § 1-111)
   B.   Deductions From Salaries; Deposits With State:
      1.   Fire Department: Deductions From Salaries: Each municipality having
a paid member of a fire department shall deduct monthly from the salary of each
member of the fire department of such municipality the following amounts:
         a.   Beginning January 1, 1981, an amount equal to four percent (4%)
of the actual paid base salary of each member of the fire department;
         b.   Beginning on January 1, 1982, an amount equal to six percent (6%)
of the actual paid base salary of each member of the fire department; and
         c.   Beginning January 1, 1983, an amount equal to eight percent (8%)
of the actual paid base salary of each member of the fire department. The
deduction shall be considered the minimum deduction. The members of a fire
department, by a majority vote of its paid members, may vote to increase the
amount of the deduction. The treasurer of each municipality shall deduct the
authorized deductions from the salary of each paid member of the fire
department. The treasurer of the municipality shall deposit monthly in the
system the amount deducted from the salary of each member of the fire
department.
      2.   Deposits With State Board: Each municipality having a paid member of
a fire department shall deposit monthly with the state board the following
amounts of money:
         a.   Commencing on January 1, 1981, an amount equal to four percent
(4%) of the total actual paid base salaries of the members of the fire
department;
         b.   Commencing on January 1, 1982, an amount equal to six percent
(6%) of the total actual paid base salaries of the members of the fire
department;
         c.   Commencing on January 1, 1983, an amount equal to eight percent
(8%) of the total actual paid base salaries of the members of the fire
department; and
         d.   Commencing on January 1, 1984, an amount equal to ten percent
(10%) of the total actual paid base salaries of the members of the fire
department.
      3.   Volunteer Members; Deductions From Salaries: Each municipality
having a volunteer member of a fire department shall deposit yearly with the
state board the following amounts of money:
         a.   Commencing on January 1, 1981, twenty dollars ($20.00) for each
volunteer member of the department;
         b.   Commencing on January 1, 1983, forty dollars ($40.00) for each
volunteer member of the department; and
         c.   Commencing on July 1, 1985, sixty dollars ($60.00) for each
volunteer member of the department. Provided, the above mentioned volunteer
municipal contributions shall be reevaluated by the next scheduled actuarial
study and the amounts adjusted so that in a nine (9) year period of time, the
amounts would reflect the actuarial recommendations at that time.
      4.   Failure To Comply: Any municipality that fails to comply with the
provisions of this section shall not be entitled to its proportionate share of
the motor fuel excise tax which is received through the Oklahoma tax
commission. Provided, however, any municipality that has heretofore exceeded
the amount of contributions required by this section is authorized to continue
making such contribution. Provided, however, that any municipality is
authorized by ordinance or charter provision to exceed the amount of
contribution required by this section.
      5.   Controlling Provisions: The provisions of this section shall
supersede any city charter provision in direct conflict with this section.
(1980 Code § 1-112)
1-7B-12: REPORTS BY FIRE CHIEF:
   A.   Report Members To Clerk: It is the duty of the chief of the fire
department to register and maintain on a current basis a report to the city
clerk containing the names of each and every member of the fire department, his
job title and service date of employment or reemployment.
   B.   Report Fires To Commission: The chief of the fire department shall make
an annual report, or periodic report if so requested, to the commission, of all
fires occurring in the city and the causes thereof. This report also shall
contain a similar documentation of fires outside the city that were attended by
the fire department. (1980 Code § 1-45)
1-7B-13: VOLUNTEER FIREFIGHTERS:
   A.   Respond To Fires: All volunteer firefighters are required, when
notified, to respond to alarms of fire and other emergencies.
   B.   Attend Meetings: Volunteer firefighters are required to be present at
all regular meetings, call meetings, and training sessions and schools
presented for the benefit of the firefighters.
   C.   Follow Orders Of Chief: Volunteer firefighters shall perform such
duties as may be directed by the fire chief.
   D.   Rules Of Conduct: Volunteer firefighters shall be subject to the same
rules of conduct as outlined in section
1-7B-7 of this article.
   E.   Dismissal For Unexcused Absences: Any volunteer having two (2)
unexcused absences in succession or three (3) unexcused absences in a three (3)
month period will be dismissed. (1980 Code § 1-46)
1-7B-14: MONTHLY MEETINGS:
To perfect the members of the fire department, regular and volunteer, in their
duties, preserve the organization thereof, and keep the fire apparatus and
department premises in good order, the department shall hold regular meetings
as the chief shall direct and at least one such meeting per month, and such
other drills as the fire chief shall prescribe. All members of the fire
department shall attend the meetings unless excused by the fire chief. (1980
Code § 1-47)
1-7B-15: SECRETARY:
One member of the fire department shall be elected to position of secretary, by
the fire department personnel, unless otherwise appointed by the fire chief,
who shall have the following duties:
   A.   Call the roll; and
   B.   Make notes of the business transacted or action taken. (1980 Code § 1-
48)
1-7B-16: ALARM OF FIRE:
The fire chief, upon an alarm of fire, shall immediately go to the place of
such fire; and all officers and members of said department shall report to him,
or to the persons having command in his absence, and at once obey his orders.
(1980 Code § 1-40)
1-7B-17: POLICE OFFICERS ACT AS FIRE GUARD:
   A.   Charge Of Property: At all fires within the city, the city police
officers shall act as fire guard, under the direction and control of the fire
chief. It shall be the duty of the fire guard to take charge and possession of
all property removed from buildings and fires, and under direction of the fire
chief restore the same to the owners thereof.
   B.   Protection Of Hose: It shall be the further duty of the fire guard to
prevent the hose from being trodden upon or injured at fires, and to so control
the crowd that the firemen shall not be hindered in their work. Any person
failing to comply with the directions or orders of the fire guard or who trod
upon, drive over or otherwise injure fire hose shall be guilty of an offense.
(1980 Code § 1-41)
1-7B-18: VEHICLES AND PEDESTRIANS; DUTY UPON ALARM OF FIRE:
   A.   Vehicles: Upon the sounding of a fire alarm, it shall be the duty and
obligation of all drivers of vehicles, of any and all kinds, to drive at once
to the right side of the street and stop and remain there until the fire alarm
ceases.
   B.   Pedestrians: All pedestrians shall clear the streets in such cases.
   C.   Violation; Penalty: Any violation of this section shall be an offense
and punished as provided by this article. (1980 Code § 1-49)
1-7B-19: FALSE ALARMS; PROHIBITED ACTS:
   A.   False Alarms: Any person who shall turn in any false fire alarm to the
Fire Department or any officer thereof, or to any other department of the City,
or cause such false alarm to be so reported shall be guilty of an offense and
punished as provided by this article.
   B.   Failure To Comply With Firefighter: Any person who shall neglect or
refuse to comply with any of the directions of the Fire Chief, an Assistant
Chief, or Fire Guard as specified in this Code or by ordinance, shall be guilty
of an offense and punished as provided by this article. (1980 Code § 1-50)
1-7B-20: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate any provisions of this article shall be guilty of
an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to penalty as
provided in section
1-4-1 of this title. (1980 Code § 1-51; amd. 2002 Code)
1-7B-21: FIRE PROTECTION FEE SCALE:
   A.   Noncity Limit Fire Run Fees:
      1.   Fees for Fire Department response to emergencies outside corporate
City limits are in line with the national standard of one-one thousandths (1/
1,000) the price of the apparatus.
 
Fire engine  $600.00 per hour
Water tanker 400.00 per hour
Brush truck  150.00 per hour
 
      2.   In lieu of these charges, an owner or resident may contract for
services from the Fire Department on an annual basis as set forth as follows:
Residential rate1:                
 3,000 sq. ft. and under        $100.00
 3,001 sq. ft. - 6,000 sq. ft.  125.00
 6,001 sq. ft. and above        150.00
Commercial rate1,2:               
 2,000 sq. ft. and under        150.00
 2,001 sq. ft. - 4,000 sq. ft.  175.00
 4,001 sq. ft. and greater      200.00
Mobile home or RV park:           
 Each occupied space            100.00
Unimproved land or agricultural:  
 1 - 80 acres                   100.00
 81 - 160 acres                 125.00
 161 - 240 acres                150.00
 Over 240 acres                 175.00
Churches:                         
 Under 10,000 sq. ft.           100.00
 Over 10,000 sq. ft.            150.00
 
      Notes:
         1.    All residential and commercial rates cover up to 80 acres of
land that the structure sits on or is adjacent to.
         2.    Commercial rate covers all buildings on site.
      3.   Oil leases, including pumping units, oil storage tanks, poly lines
and saltwater tanks will not be included in any annual subscription fee. They
will be charged an hourly rate plus cost of extinguishing agents and cost of
damaged equipment, i.e., damaged hose, PPE or apparatus. Furthermore, cost of
hazardous material mitigation may be included. (Ord. 328, 12-11-2017; amd. Ord.
349, 4-8-2024)
ARTICLE C. STREETS AND PARKS DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
1-7C-1: Created; Supervision
1-7C-2: Duties
1-7C-3: Employees
1-7C-1: CREATED; SUPERVISION:
A streets and parks department for the city is hereby created. The head of this
department shall be the streets and parks superintendent appointed for an
indefinite term by the city manager. The department shall function under the
supervision and guidance of such superintendent. (Ord. 259, 1-12-2009)
1-7C-2: DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the streets and parks department to maintain and
improve the streets and alleyways within the city, maintain the parks,
playgrounds and cemeteries, mow and otherwise maintain the rights of way owned
by the city of Drumright, maintain and improve the drainageways within the
city, maintain city streetlights owned by the city, and to perform other such
duties as may be assigned by the city manager. (Ord. 259, 1-12-2009)
1-7C-3: EMPLOYEES:
The streets and parks department shall have such employees as may be authorized
and funded by the board of commissioners. All employees shall be under the
supervision and direction of the streets and parks superintendent. (Ord. 259,
1-12-2009)
ARTICLE D. WATER AND SEWER DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
1-7D-1: Department Created; Supervision
1-7D-2: Duties
1-7D-3: Employees
1-7D-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED; SUPERVISION:
A water and sewer department for the city is hereby created. The head of this
department shall be the water and sewer superintendent, appointed for an
indefinite term by the city manager. The department shall function under the
supervision and guidance of such superintendent. (1980 Code § 1-56)
1-7D-2: DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the water and sewer department to maintain, improve,
and operate the municipally owned water and sewer system, including treatment
and disposal. (1980 Code § 1-57)
1-7D-3: EMPLOYEES:
The water and sewer department shall have such employees as may be authorized
and funded by the board of commissioners. All employees shall be under the
supervision of the water and sewer superintendent. (1980 Code § 1-58)
ARTICLE E. SANITATION DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
1-7E-1: Function
1-7E-1: FUNCTION:
The municipal function of solid waste collection shall be performed through a
contractual arrangement with an individual or company licensed to perform such
operations by the department of environmental quality of the state of Oklahoma.
Any such contract shall be approved by the board of city commissioners. The
contract shall be administered by the city manager. (Ord. 259, 1-12-2009)
ARTICLE F. PARK DEPARTMENT
(Rep. by Ord. 259, 1-12-2009)
ARTICLE G. CEMETERY DEPARTMENT
(Rep. by Ord. 259, 1-12-2009)
ARTICLE H. COOPERATIVE HEALTH DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
1-7H-1: County Department; Director
1-7H-2: Duties
1-7H-1: COUNTY DEPARTMENT; DIRECTOR:
The cooperative health department of the county and its director shall have the
powers and duties of a city health department and city health officer
respectively for the city. References to health department and health officer
or director of the health department in this code and in other ordinances of
the city shall be deemed to mean the cooperative health department of the
county and its director, unless the context clearly indicates another meaning.
(1980 Code § 1-68)
1-7H-2: DUTIES:
The county cooperative department of health shall perform such duties, and have
such powers, as may be prescribed by ordinance, law, and the rules and
regulations of the state department of health. (1980 Code § 1-69)
CHAPTER 8
CITY FINANCES
SECTION:
1-8-1: Funding And Accounting
1-8-2: Deposit Of Funds
1-8-3: Purchases; Contracts
1-8-4: Invoices
1-8-5: Warrants; Disbursement Of Funds
1-8-6: Bonds, Issuance
1-8-7: Examination And Audit Of Books And Records
1-8-8: Insurance For Property, Vehicles
1-8-9: Penalty
1-8-1: FUNDING AND ACCOUNTING:
   A.   Generally: The revenues and other resources of the city shall be
divided into funds as provided by 62 Oklahoma Statutes section 331, and other
applicable provisions of law; and accounted for as provided thereby. (1980 Code
§ 7-24)
   B.   Sinking Fund:
      1.   It shall be the duty of the officers of the city to handle, deposit,
invest and use the money in the sinking fund of the city in the manner provided
by the 62 Oklahoma Statutes sections 431 through 451, and any other applicable
provisions of law.
      2.   The city treasurer shall deposit daily all uninvested sinking fund
money in his hands in banks as provided by law. (1980 Code § 7-25)
   C.   Investment Of Water Meter Deposits: Money deposited with the city as
water meter deposits may be invested as provided by 11 Oklahoma Statutes
section 35-102.1. (1980 Code § 7-26; amd. 2002 Code)
1-8-2: DEPOSIT OF FUNDS:
The funds of the city shall be deposited as required by law. (1980 Code § 7-27;
amd. 2002 Code)
1-8-3: PURCHASES; CONTRACTS 1 :
   A.   City Officers Restricted:
      1.   No member of the city commission may sell, or furnish for a
consideration, any materials or supplies for use of the city; and any member of
the city commission voting for, or consenting to, or being a party to, such
contract or purchase is personally liable as provided by 62 Oklahoma Statutes
sections 355 and 357.
      2.   The city commission shall not make any contract with any of its
members, or in which any of its members shall be directly or indirectly
interested, such contracts being prohibited by 62 Oklahoma Statutes section
371.
      3.   No officer of the city may become directly or indirectly interested
individually in any sale, lease or contract which he is authorized to make,
such being prohibited by 21 Oklahoma Statutes section 344. (1980 Code § 7-28)
   B.   Authority Of City Manager: All purchases of supplies, materials,
equipment and contractual services for the city, and any sales thereof by the
city, shall be made by the city manager pursuant to authorization granted by
the city commission, and subject to its supervision and control. (1980 Code §
7-29)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 1-6A-6 of this title.
1-8-4: INVOICES:
   A.   Affidavit Required On Certain Invoices: On every invoice submitted to
the state or any county or local subdivision of the state for payment to an
architect, contractor, engineer or supplier of material of one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) or more shall be the following signed and notarized statement:
   STATE OF OKLAHOMA   )
   COUNTY OF         )
   The undersigned (architect, contractor, supplier or engineer) of lawful age,
being first duly sworn on oath, says that this invoice or claim is true and
correct. Affiant further states that the (work, services or materials) as shown
by this invoice or claim have been (completed or supplied) in accordance with
the plans, specifications, orders or requests furnished the affiant. Affiant
further states that (s)he has made no payment directly or indirectly to any
