elected official, officer or employee of the State of Oklahoma, any county or
local subdivision of the state, of money or any other thing of value to obtain
payment.
                                                                           
            (Architect, Contractor, Supplier or Engineer)
   Subscribed and sworn to before me this       day of           , 20     .
                                                             
            (Notary Public, or Clerk or Judge)
   B.   Applicability: Subsection A this section shall not apply to monthly
billings submitted to the state for public utility companies or telephone
companies whose services are regulated by the Oklahoma corporation commission,
but will apply to said utility companies or telephone companies for billings
pertaining to installations or changes in service. (1980 Code § 7-31)
1-8-5: WARRANTS; DISBURSEMENT OF FUNDS:
Warrants shall be issued and processed and funds of the city disbursed only for
legal purposes and in accordance with 62 Oklahoma Statutes sections 372, 471
through 485, and 551 through 555. (1980 Code § 7-32)
1-8-6: BONDS, ISSUANCE:
Bonds of the city shall be issued, sold, paid and handled in all respects as
provided by 62 Oklahoma Statutes section 331 et seq., and other applicable
provisions of law. (1980 Code § 7-33)
1-8-7: EXAMINATION AND AUDIT OF BOOKS AND RECORDS:
   A.   Examination By Commission: The books of the city treasurer shall be
subject to examination by the city commission at all times, as provided by
Oklahoma Statutes, and the city charter. Likewise the records of the city clerk
and of all other officers and employees of the city shall be subject to
inspection by the city commission at all times.
   B.   Audit By Accountant: The city commission shall designate a qualified
public accountant to audit the financial records and transactions of the city
treasurer, the city clerk, and all other personnel of the city who keep
financial records and make financial transactions, as of the end of every
fiscal year at least, and such accountant shall make such audit and shall
report to the city commission. (1980 Code § 7-34)
1-8-8: INSURANCE FOR PROPERTY, VEHICLES:
   A.   Property: The city commission may insure property of the city as
authorized by 19 Oklahoma Statutes section 627. Any money received as a result
of destruction, damages or loss of such insured property shall be accounted for
and used as provided by said section.
   B.   Vehicles: The city commission may purchase insurance to pay damage to
persons sustaining injuries or damages to property as a result of negligent
operation of motor vehicles or motorized equipment of the city, as authorized
by Oklahoma Statutes. (1980 Code § 7-35; amd. 2002 Code)
1-8-9: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate or fail to comply with any
provision of this chapter or of any provisions adopted herein, or any legal
order or regulation made pursuant thereto, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor
and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to penalty as provided in
section
1-4-1 of this title. Each day upon which a violation shall continue shall be
deemed a separate offense. (1980 Code § 7-41; amd. 2002 Code)
CHAPTER 9
ELECTIONS; WARDS AND BOUNDARIES
SECTION:
1-9-1: Corporate Limits
1-9-2: Ward Boundaries
1-9-3: Polling Places In Public Buildings
1-9-4: Absentee Ballots
1-9-1: CORPORATE LIMITS:
The corporate limits of the city shall be as shown on the official city map on
file in the office of the city clerk. (2002 Code)

the centerline of East Cherry Street to the centerline of North Pennsylvania

Broadway/State Highway 33 approximately 1.5 miles to the Drumright corporate
limit boundary, thence north continuing along the corporate limit boundary
approximately 2,479 feet, thence east approximately 7,736 feet, thence south
approximately 2,370 feet to the centerline of State Highway 33, thence east
along the centerline of State Highway 33 approximately 289 feet to the
Drumright corporate limit boundary, thence north continuing to follow the
corporate limit boundary approximately 2,571 feet, thence west approximately 2
miles to the centerline of State Highway 99/Drumright corporate limit boundary,
thence north along the centerline of State Highway 99/Drumright corporate limit
boundary approximately 6,616 feet, thence west continuing along corporate limit
boundary approximately 5,604 feet to the centerline of unnamed dirt lease road,
thence continuing along the centerline of unnamed dirt lease road south and
southeast to the centerline of North Smathers Avenue, thence southeast and
south along the centerline of North Smathers Avenue to the centerline of State
Highway 33 Bypass said point also being the point of beginning.
(Ord. 309, 1-12-2015)
   B.   Voting Precincts: Each ward shall contain one voting precinct only, and
the boundaries of said voting precinct shall coincide with the boundaries of
said ward. Each precinct in each ward shall be precinct 1 of that particular
ward.
   C.   Annexations: The ward and precinct of each and all additions and other
areas hereinafter added or annexed to the city shall be determined by the
boundaries above described herein, and the streets set out as such boundaries
shall be considered as extended through or past said new additions or areas,
insofar as is necessary to determine the precinct and ward of any such new
additions. (1980 Code § 22-2; amd. 2002 Code)
1-9-3: POLLING PLACES IN PUBLIC BUILDINGS:
No polling place for elections held within the city shall be in any building
which is not a public building. (1980 Code § 22-3)
1-9-4: ABSENTEE BALLOTS:
   A.   Not Prohibited By Charter: The city is a charter city and said charter
does not specifically prohibit voting by absentee ballots.
   B.   Absentee Ballots Authorized: Pursuant to the authority granted by 26
Oklahoma Statutes section 14-101, as amended, absentee ballots shall be
provided in all municipal elections of the city. The issuance of, and the
voting by, such absentee ballots shall be pursuant to the statutes of the state
governing absentee voting. (Ord. 203, 1-5-1995)
CHAPTER 10
MUNICIPAL COURT
SECTION:

1-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, unless the context requires a different meaning, the
following words shall mean:
CHIEF OF POLICE: The peace officer in charge of the police department of the
city of Drumright, Oklahoma.
CLERK: The clerk of the city of Drumright, including any deputy or member of
the office staff of said clerk while performing duties of the clerk's office.
COURT: The municipal court, not of record, of the city of Drumright, Oklahoma.
JUDGE: The judge of the municipal court, not of record, aforesaid, including
any acting or alternate judge thereof as provided by the statutes of the state
of Oklahoma and by this chapter.
THIS JUDICIAL DISTRICT: The district court judicial district of the state of
Oklahoma, in which the city of Drumright is situated. (1980 Code § 12-2)
1-10-2: COURT CREATED:
This chapter shall govern the creation, organization and operation of the
municipal court, a court not of record, of the city, as put into operation by
resolution duly passed by the city commission on October 7, 1980, and filed
pursuant to the provisions of 11 Oklahoma Statutes section 27-102. If any
conflict exists between the provisions of this chapter and any other ordinance
of the city, the provisions of this chapter shall control. Said court shall be
operative on and after December 31, 1980. (1980 Code § 12-1)
1-10-3: JUDGE OF THE COURT:
   A.   Appointment; Qualifications: There shall be a judge of the court, who
shall be licensed to practice law within the state of Oklahoma and shall be
appointed, and, when necessary for the good of service, dismissed by the city
manager as provided in article V, section 34 of the Drumright city charter. In
addition, the city commission may, at any meeting where the item is placed on
the agenda in accordance with state law, by a majority vote of all its members
direct the dismissal of the municipal judge. (Ord. 274, 6-14-2010)
   B.   Term Of Office: The municipal judge shall serve for a term of two (2)
years and until his successor is appointed and qualified unless sooner removed
by the vote of a majority of all members of the board of commissioners for such
cause as is provided by law for the removal of public officials. The first term
of the municipal judge shall begin December 31, 1980. Any appointment to fill a
vacancy shall be for the unexpired portion of the current term.
   C.   Practice In Other Courts: The judge may engage in the practice of law
in other courts, but he shall not accept employment inconsistent with his
duties as judge, or arising out of facts which give rise to, or are connected
with cases within the jurisdiction of the court, which are pending therein, or
which might become the subject of proceedings therein. The judge must either
reside in or maintain a permanent office in the city.
   D.   Salary: The judge shall be paid a salary to be fixed by the board of
commissioners and shall be paid in the same manner as other city officials.
   E.   Absence Of Judge; Acting Judge: In the event of the disqualification of
the judge in a particular case, or his absence or inability to act, the mayor
may appoint some other person, qualified as provided above in this section, as
acting municipal judge of the court in place of the judge during his absence or
inability to act or in a case where the judge is disqualified. Such acting
municipal judge shall be compensated as the board of commissioners shall
direct.
   F.   Vacancy In Office: A vacancy in the office of judge shall occur if the
incumbent:
      1.   Is deceased;
      2.   Resigns;
      3.   Ceases to possess the qualifications for the office; or
      4.   Is removed and the removal proceedings have been affirmed by a
tribunal of final jurisdiction or are no longer subject to appellate review.
   G.   Appoint Successor: Upon the occurrence of a vacancy in the office of
judge, the mayor shall appoint a successor to complete the unexpired term using
the same procedure as in making the original appointment.
   H.   Responsibility: The judge shall be personally responsible for carrying
out all acts and duties provided in this chapter.
   I.   Removal Procedure; Hearing:
      1.   Proceedings for the removal of a judge shall be instituted by the
filing of a verified, written petition setting forth facts sufficient to
constitute one or more legal grounds for removal. Petitions may be signed and
filed either by the mayor or by twenty five (25) or more qualified electors of
the city. In the latter event, verification may be by one or more of the
petitioners.
      2.   If such petition be filed, the board of commissioners shall set a
date for hearing the matter and shall cause notice thereof, together with a
copy of the petition to be served personally on the judge at least ten (10)
days before the hearing. At the hearing, the judge shall be entitled to
representation by counsel, shall be entitled to present testimony and to cross
examine the witnesses against him and to have all evidence against him
presented in an open hearing.
      3.   So far as they are applicable, the provisions of the statutes of the
state governing individual officer removal proceedings, and any amendments or
additions thereto, shall govern hereunder.
      4.   Judgment of removal shall be entered only upon individual votes by a
majority of all members of the board of commissioners in favor of such removal.
(1980 Code § 12-4)
1-10-4: NO CHANGE OF VENUE; DISQUALIFICATION OF JUDGES:
In the trial of matters before the court, no change of venue shall be allowed;
but the judge may certify his disqualification or he may be disqualified from
sitting under the terms, conditions and procedures provided by law for courts
of record. If the judge is disqualified, the matter shall be heard by an
alternate or acting judge, appointed as provided in this chapter. (1980 Code §
12-5)
1-10-5: CITY ATTORNEY TO BE PROSECUTING ATTORNEY:
The attorney for the city shall be the prosecuting officer of the court. He
shall prosecute all alleged violations of the ordinances of the city. He shall
be authorized, in his discretion, to prosecute and resist appeals, proceedings
in error and review from this court to any other court of the state and to
represent the city in all proceedings arising out of matters in this court. He
shall receive additional compensation for appellate work as the board of
commissioners shall direct. (1980 Code § 12-6)
1-10-6: CLERK OF COURT; DUTIES:
The city clerk or a deputy designated by said clerk, shall be the clerk of the
court. The clerk shall:
   A.   Assist the judge in recording the proceedings of the court and in
preparation of writs, processes, or other papers.
   B.   Administer oaths required in judicial or other proceedings before the
court.
   C.   Be responsible for the entry of all pleadings, processes, and
proceedings in the dockets of the court.
   D.   Perform such other clerical duties in relation to the proceedings of
the court as the judge shall direct. (1980 Code § 12-7)
   E.   Receive and give receipt for and disburse or deliver to the city
treasurer, all fines, forfeitures, fees, deposits, and sums of money properly
payable to the municipal court. Such funds and sums of money while in the
custody of the clerk, shall be deposited and disbursed upon vouchers as
directed by the board of commissioners. The clerk shall pay to the treasurer of
the city on the first business day following court, all monies so received by
said clerk, except such special deposits or fees as shall be received to be
disbursed by the clerk for special purposes. All monies paid to the treasurer
shall be placed in the general fund of the city, or in such other fund as the
board of commissioners may direct, and it shall be used in the operation of the
municipal government in accordance with budgetary arrangements governing the
fund in which it is placed. (1980 Code § 12-7; amd. 2002 Code)
1-10-7: POLICE CHIEF TO BE MARSHAL OF COURT:
The chief of police of the city or his designated representative shall be the
marshal of the court. The marshal shall execute any writs and other processes
directed to him, except as provided otherwise in this chapter, and this duty
may be performed by any deputy marshal, or by any member of the police force of
the city. (1980 Code § 12-8)
1-10-8: CLERK BONDED:
The clerk of the court shall give bond to the board of commissioners in the
form provided by 11 Oklahoma Statutes section 27-111, and amendments thereto,
in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). When executed, said bonds
shall be submitted to the board of commissioners for approval, and when
approved, shall be filed with the city manager and retained in his permanent
records. (1980 Code § 12-9; amd. 2002 Code)
1-10-9: POWERS AND AUTHORITY OF JUDGE:
   A.   Prescribe Rules: The judge of the court may prescribe rules, consistent
with the provisions of this chapter, for the proper conduct of the business of
the municipal court. (1980 Code § 12-10)
   B.   Enforce Ordinances: The judge shall have power to enforce due obedience
to all orders, rules or judgments made by him and may fine or imprison for
contempt offered to the judge while holding his court or to any process issued
by him in the same manner and to the same extent as the district courts of the
state. (1980 Code § 12-11)
   C.   Supervise Juveniles: In addition to his other duties, the judge of the
municipal court shall supervise all juveniles who are either on parole or
serving probation terms or suspended sentences pronounced and adjudged by the
municipal court. (1980 Code § 12-12)
1-10-10: CODE OF PROCEDURE IN COURT:
The code of procedure in the municipal court shall be the same as provided by
state statute for the trial of misdemeanors. The court shall take judicial
notice of all state statutes and the ordinances of the city. Writs and
processes of the court shall be issued either by the judge or the clerk to any
proper officer. All writs and processes of the municipal court wherein a
violation of a city ordinance is charged, shall be directed to the marshal or
the chief of police of the city, or to some other appropriate peace officer.
(1980 Code § 12-13)
1-10-11: STYLE OF PROSECUTIONS; COMPLAINTS:
All prosecutions commenced in the municipal court shall be by complaint which
shall be subscribed by the person making the complaint and shall be verified
before the judge, the clerk of the court, or a police officer. However, no
warrant for arrest shall be issued until the complaint has been approved by the
city attorney or the judge of the municipal court. All prosecutions for the
violation of city ordinances shall be styled, "The City of Drumright -vs-
(naming the person or persons charged)". (1980 Code § 12-14)
1-10-12: ARRAIGNMENTS; DEMANDING OR WAIVING TRIAL:
   A.   Plea By Defendant: Arraignment shall be made by the court. The judge
shall read the complaint to the defendant, inform him of his legal rights, and
of the consequences of conviction, and ask him whether he pleads guilty or not
guilty.
   B.   Demand Or Waive Trial: At arraignment, the judge shall ask the
defendant whether he demands or waives trial by jury. The judge shall cause his
election to be recorded in the minutes of the arraignment and entered on the
docket of the court respecting proceedings in the case.
   C.   Changing Decision: An election waiving jury trial, made at time of
arraignment, may be changed by the defendant at any time prior to the day for
which trial by the court is set. An election demanding jury trial by the
defendant may be changed at any time prior to the commencement of proceedings
to impanel the jury for said trial, but if that change occurs after the case
has been set for jury trial, it may not thereafter be rechanged so as again to
demand trial by jury. (1980 Code § 12-15)
1-10-13: ARRESTS; BAIL:
   A.   Acknowledge Receipt Of Citation: Whenever a resident of the city is
arrested for violation of any ordinance, traffic or nontraffic, by a law
enforcement officer, the officer shall immediately release such person if he
acknowledges receipt of a citation by signing it, unless it reasonably appears
to the officer that the person may cause injury to himself or others or damage
to property if released, or that the person will not appear in response to the
citation. If such person fails to appear in response to the citation, a warrant
shall be issued for his arrest and his appearance shall be compelled.
   B.   Arrest Of Resident: Whenever a resident of the city is arrested by a
law enforcement officer for the violation of any ordinance and is not released
by being permitted to sign a citation as provided in subsection A of this
section, he shall be admitted to bail either before or after arraignment, or
released on his own recognizance.
   C.   Arrest Of Nonresident: Whenever a nonresident of the city is arrested
for a violation of any ordinance, by a law enforcement officer, the defendant
shall be eligible to be admitted to bail either before or after arraignment,
unless it reasonably appears to the officer that the person may cause injury to
himself or others or damage to property, if released. The method of posting
bail shall be as set out in subsection D of this section.
   D.   Method Of Posting Bail: Any resident of the city arrested for the
violation of any ordinance, who is not released pursuant to subsection A of
this section, shall be entitled to be released upon posting bail, and the
methods of posting bail shall be as follows:
      1.   Posting cash bail;
      2.   Depositing with the arresting officer a "guaranteed arrest bond
certificate"; or
      3.   Depositing with the arresting officer a valid license to operate a
motor vehicle in exchange for a receipt therefor issued by the arresting
officer, which shall be recognized as an operator's license and shall authorize
the person's operation of a motor vehicle to the date of his hearing but not to
exceed twenty (20) days.
   E.   Rules For Receipt Of Bail:
      1.   The amount and conditions of bail granted under subsections B, C and
D of this section shall be determined by the judge who shall prescribe a set of
rules for the receipt of bail and for the release by recognizance. In the event
of arrests at night, or other emergency, or when the judge is not available,
the chief of police or his designated representative shall be authorized by the
judge, under such conditions as shall be prescribed by the judge, to accept a
temporary cash bond in a sufficient amount to secure the appearance of the
accused, but in no event shall the cash bond be more than the maximum fine
provided by ordinance for each offense charged. The chief of police or his
designated representative is authorized, subject to such conditions as shall be
prescribed by the judge, to release a resident of the city on his own
recognizance.
      2.   The judge of the court shall prepare and furnish a detailed set of
rules for the receipt of bail and for the release by recognizance pursuant to
the provisions of this subsection, including the amounts and conditions of bail
for all offenses. (1980 Code § 12-16)
1-10-14: FAILURE TO APPEAR IN COURT; BOND FORFEITURE 1 :
   A.   Failure To Appear; Forfeiture Of Surety Or Property Bond:
      1.   If a defendant has been released on a "surety or property bond" or
upon a bond made by a professional bondsman and, without sufficient excuse,
said defendant fails to appear according to the terms or conditions of his
bond, either for hearing, arraignment, trial or judgment, or upon any other
occasion when his presence in court may be lawfully required, the Municipal
Judge shall direct that fact to be entered upon the court minutes and declare
the bond forfeited. (1980 Code § 12-17)
      2.   The Municipal Judge shall then, without advancing court costs,
certify the forfeiture to the District Court of Creek County, and cause same to
be entered upon the judgment docket, and the Municipal Judge shall be
responsible for effecting collection of said bond with the help of the District
Court Clerk pursuant to the provisions of 59 Oklahoma Statutes sections 1331
through 1333 and 1335. Court costs shall be collectible from the proceeds of
the bond. (1980 Code § 12-17; amd. 2002 Code)
   B.   Forfeiture Of Cash Bond: If a defendant has been released on a cash
bond, and fails to appear according to the terms or conditions of his bond,
either for hearing, arraignment, trial or judgment, or any other occasion when
his presence in court may be lawfully required, the cash bond shall be
forfeited, and said monies deposited as other fines, and receipts of monies
from defendants. (1980 Code § 12-17)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 5-1E-7 of this code.
1-10-15: TRIAL BY JURY:
Trial by jury shall be had in all cases punishable by a fine of more than one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or by imprisonment, or by both such fine and
imprisonment, unless such jury trial is waived by both the defendant and the
City. (Ord. 325, 7-10-2017)
1-10-16: JUDGMENT RENDERED AND ENTERED:
If the defendant pleads guilty or is convicted after trial, the court must
render judgment thereof, and may fix the punishment as provided in section
1-4-1 of this title. (Ord. 236, 1-23-2003)
1-10-17: JURORS:
   A.   Composition; Qualifications: A jury in the Municipal Court shall
consist of six (6) jurors, five (5) of whom may return a verdict. Jurors shall
be good and lawful men or women, citizens of Creek County, having the
qualifications of jurors in the District Court.
   B.   Selection: Jurors in the Municipal Court of the City shall be selected
under the same terms and conditions as are provided by law for the District
Courts.
   C.   Terms: Jury terms shall be scheduled as needed, but in no event less
frequently than twice yearly, if there is any case on the court calendar for
trial by jury. Such terms shall be called by the Judge of the court, and shall
be held during the months of January and July of each year, (if there are cases
for jury trial), and at such other times as the Judge may direct.
   D.   Request For Jurors From District Court: Whenever a calendar of cases
has been made up by the Judge of the court for trial of cases by jury, the
Judge of the Municipal Court shall make written request to the Chief Judge of
the District Court of Creek County, for a stated number of jurors and the
Municipal Judge shall superintend the Clerk of the District Court in drawing
from the jury wheel the requested number of jurors in the same manner as is
provided by law for the District Court until the number of jurors requested,
who from their addresses appear to reside within the corporate limits of the
City are drawn. The District Court Clerk shall then prepare a list of the names
drawn and certify such list to the Judge of the Municipal Court. If, after
allowance of claimed statutory exemptions for jurors, the listed number is
found to be insufficient, the Municipal Judge shall make a written request to
the Chief Judge of the District Court for a stated number of additional jurors.
(1980 Code § 12-20)
   E.   Summons: Upon receipt of the jury list, the Clerk of the court shall
prepare and cause a summons substantially in the following form to be issued
and served upon each person on the list:
   STATE OF OKLAHOMA   )
               ) ss:
   COUNTY OF CREEK   )
   TO (Name of Juror), GREETING:
You are hereby summoned to appear in the Municipal Court within and for the
City of Drumright, to be held at the Court Room in the City Hall Building on
the        day of              , 20     , at the hour of        A.M., to serve
as a Juror in said court, and to continue in such service until discharged by
the court.
   Hereof fail not under penalty of law.
Issued under the authority of said Court, this      day of                  ,
20     .
                                               
      CLERK of the Municipal Court
      Drumright, Oklahoma
   (S E A L)
   (1980 Code § 12-20; amd. 2002 Code)
   F.   Serving Summons: Juror summons may be served in person by the chief of
police or any member of the police force of the city, or may be served by the
clerk of said court by mail.
   G.   Advance Selection Of Jurors; Notice: The request made by the municipal
judge for jurors shall be accomplished a sufficient time in advance of the
beginning of the jury term to enable the proper officials to draw the jury,
certify same, and enable the clerk to summon said jurors a minimum of one week
in advance of the beginning of said jury term.
   H.   Challenges Allowed: In selecting a jury, each side shall be allowed two
(2) preemptory challenges. There shall be no limit on the number of challenges
for cause.
   I.   Hearing Of Evidence: After the jury is selected and sworn, they must
sit together and hear the evidence and oral arguments of the parties, all of
which must be presented in public and in the presence of the defendant.
   J.   Foreman Selection; Render Verdict: After the case is submitted to the
jury, they must select one of their number as foreman. If as many as five (5)
jurors agree, they may render a verdict and the verdict must be signed by all
five (5). If the verdict is unanimous, the foreman alone may sign.
   K.   Deliver Verdict To Court: The verdict of the jury, in all cases, must
be general. When the jury has arrived at its verdict, it must deliver the
verdict publicly to the court. The judge must enter the verdict in the docket
or cause it to be so entered.
   L.   Discharge Of Jurors: After the cause is submitted to the jury, the jury
must not be discharged until a verdict is rendered, unless the judge, for good
cause, declares a mistrial and discharges said jury. In the event of mistrial,
said cause shall be retried at the next available jury term. (1980 Code § 12-
20)
   M.   Compensation: Jurors shall receive for their services, the sum of
twelve dollars ($12.00) per day, plus mileage as allowed by the internal
revenue service for each mile necessarily traveled by the most direct route in
going to and from the court from their places of residences. The claims for
such compensation shall show the location of the juror's residence and must be
verified as other claims against the city are verified. Jurors shall be paid
out of the general fund of the city. (1980 Code § 12-20; amd. 2002 Code)
1-10-18: WITNESSES:
   A.   Compensation:
      1.   Witnesses in any proceeding in the court, other than police officers
or peace officers, shall be entitled to five dollars ($5.00) per day for each
day of attendance plus mileage as allowed by the internal revenue service for
each mile actually and necessarily traveled in going to and returning from
attendance at court, but such mileage shall be paid only once for each week of
service.
      2.   No witness shall receive fees or mileage in more than one case for
the same period of time or the same travel.
      3.   A defendant seeking to subpoena witnesses must deposit with the
clerk of the court, a sum sufficient to cover fees and mileage for the time
required for the attendance of said witness and for the distance to be traveled
by said witness. However, an indigent defendant who files with the clerk an
affidavit, setting out the following facts, shall not be required to deposit
such sums:
         a.   The names and addresses of not more than three (3) witnesses.
         b.   That the defendant by reason of his poverty is unable to pay the
fees and mileage allowed by law.
         c.   That the testimony of said witnesses is material.
         d.   That their attendance at the trial is necessary for his proper
defense.
   B.   Payment By City: The fees and mileage of said witnesses, for an
indigent defendant, shall be paid by the city. (1980 Code § 12-21; amd. 2002
Code)
1-10-19: JUDGMENT:
   A.   Judgment: At the close of trial, judgment must be rendered immediately
by the judge who shall cause it to be entered in his docket. (1980 Code § 12-
22)
   B.   Acquittal: If judgment is of acquittal, and the defendant is not to be
detained for any other legal cause, he must be discharged at once. (1980 Code §
12-23)
1-10-20: FINES AND COURT COSTS:
   A.   Collection Of Fines: If judgment of conviction is entered, the clerk of
the court shall tax the costs to the defendant in the sum of twenty five
dollars ($25.00) plus the fees and mileage of jurors and witnesses, all of
which the defendant shall pay, in addition to any fine or jail term that may be
imposed.
   B.   Court Costs: Court costs in all cases tried in the municipal court
shall be the sum of twenty five dollars ($25.00) plus the fees and mileage, if
any, of jurors and witnesses. (Ord. 218, 11-2-1999)
   C.   Technology Fee: Effective July 1, 2016, the city commission of the city
of Drumright assesses a technology fee for the acquisition, operation,
maintenance, repair, and replacement of data processing equipment and software
for the Drumright court system in the amount of twenty five dollars ($25.00)
per conviction. (Ord. 321, 5-9-2016)
   D.   Payment Of Fines:
      1.   If a defendant who is financially able refuses or neglects to pay a
fine or costs or both, payment may be enforced by imprisonment until the same
shall be satisfied at the rate of five dollars ($5.00) per day.
      2.   If the defendant is without means to pay the fine or costs, the
municipal judge may direct the total amount due to be entered upon the court
minutes and the municipal judge shall cause to be certified to the district
court of Creek County, said judgment where it shall be entered upon the
district court judgment docket and shall have the full force and effect of a
district court judgment, and the city shall have the same remedies for the
enforcement of said judgment as are available to any other judgment creditor.
(1980 Code § 12-25; amd. 2002 Code; Ord. 321, 5-9-2016)
      3.   The clerk of the court shall tax the defendant in a sum not
exceeding thirty dollars ($30.00) plus the fees and mileage of jurors and
witnesses, all of which the defendant shall pay, in addition to any fine or
administrative fees that may be imposed, and in addition to any state mandated
fees or costs. No court cost will be assessed for parking or seat belt
violations.
      4.   A collection fee of thirty five percent (35%) of court penalties,
costs, fines, and fees in cases in which the accused has failed to appear or
otherwise failed to satisfy a monetary obligation imposed by the court shall be
added to any such case which is referred to a collection agency for collection.
(Ord. 301, 10-15-2013, eff. 10-15-2013; amd. Ord. 321, 5-9-2016)
1-10-21: JUDICIAL DISCRETION:
   A.   Decision Of Judge: Whenever any person shall plead guilty to, or shall
be convicted of, violating a city ordinance, the judge, after imposing the
sentence, may suspend the judgment, or costs or both, and allow the person so
convicted to be released upon his own recognizance. Any person so released
shall be required to report to the judge of the court at such time as the judge
shall direct. The judge may cause a warrant to be issued for any person so
released if it shall be made to appear to the judge that such person:
      1.   Has been guilty of the violation of any law after his release;
      2.   Is habitually associating with lewd or vicious persons; or
      3.   Is indulging in vicious habits.
   B.   Payment Of Fine Or Imprisonment: Upon the issuance of the warrant by
the judge, the person shall be delivered forthwith to the city jail and shall
either pay the fine imposed, plus court costs, or serve out the full term for
which he was originally sentenced. (1980 Code § 12-26)
1-10-22: APPEALS:
An appeal may be taken from a final judgment of the municipal court of the city
to the district court of Creek County.
   A.   File Notice Of Appeal: To commence the appeal, the defendant must file
in the district court of Creek County, within ten (10) days from the date of
the final judgment, a notice of appeal and must also file a copy of said notice
with the clerk of the municipal court. (1980 Code § 12-28)
   B.   Trial De Novo: In case of an appeal, a trial de novo shall be had and
there shall be a right to a jury trial if the offense is punishable by a fine
of more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), plus costs. (1980 Code § 12-28;
amd. 2002 Code)
   C.   Order For Bond: Upon conviction, at the request of the defendant, or
upon notice of appeal being filed, the judge of the municipal court shall enter
an order on his docket fixing an amount in which bond may be given by the
defendant, in cash or sureties for cash, in an amount of not less than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00); except
that, if the conviction involved a fine only, the amount of the bond shall be
no greater than twice the amount of such fine. Bond shall be taken by the clerk
of the court wherein judgment was rendered. Any pledge of sureties must be
approved by the judge of the court.
   D.   Appellate Court:
      1.   Certification Of Original Papers: Upon appeal being filed, the judge
of the municipal court shall, within ten (10) days thereafter, certify to the
clerk of the appellate court, the original papers in the case. If the papers
have not been so certified within ten (10) days, the city attorney shall take
the necessary steps to cause the judge to have the papers certified to the
appellate court within twenty (20) days of the judgment. Failure to so certify
within twenty (20) days, except for good cause shown, shall be grounds for
dismissal of the charge by the appellate court with the costs to be taxed to
the city. The certificate shall state whether or not the municipal judge
hearing the case was a licensed attorney in Oklahoma.
      2.   Judgment: All proceedings necessary to carry the judgment into
effect shall be had in the appellate court. (1980 Code § 12-28)
1-10-23: STATE SUPREME COURT:
   A.   Supervision: This municipal court shall be under the general
superintending control of the supreme court of the state of Oklahoma, and the
judge thereof shall be subject to all orders of the supreme court and shall
attend any conference of municipal judges called by the chief justice of the
supreme court of the state of Oklahoma. (1980 Code § 12-29)
   B.   Subject To Issuance Of Writs: This court shall be subject to writs of
mandamus, prohibition and certiorari issued by the district court of Creek
County, in the same manner as the supreme court has authority to issue such
writs to courts of record. (1980 Code § 10-31)
1-10-24: REPEAL OF PENALTY CLAUSES WHERE APPLICABLE:
All presently existing ordinances and subsections thereof of the city which
limit punishment for the commission of offenses against the city and for the
violation of its ordinances to a lesser punishment than provided herein are
hereby repealed. (1980 Code § 12-30)
1-10-25: PENALTY ASSESSMENT:
   A.   Definition: As used in this section, "convicted" means any final
adjudication of guilt, whether pursuant to a plea of guilty or nolo contendere
or otherwise, and any deferred or suspended sentence or judgment.
   B.   Penalty Imposed:
      1.   Any person convicted of an offense punishable by a fine of ten
dollars ($10.00) or more or by incarceration, excluding parking and standing
violations, or any person forfeiting bond when charged with such an offense,
shall be ordered by the court to pay ten dollars ($10.00) as a separate penalty
assessment, which shall be in addition to and not in substitution for any and
all fines and penalties otherwise provided for by law for such offense.
      2.   The court shall provide for separate bail for the penalty
assessment. A defendant admitted to bail on an undertaking by a surety may
include the amount of the penalty assessment in the undertaking.
   C.   Administrative Fee: Upon conviction or bond forfeiture, the court shall
collect the penalty assessment and deposit it in an account created for that
purpose. As an administrative fee for handling funds collected as a penalty
assessment, the court is authorized to retain eight cents ($0.08) per
administrative fee and may also retain all interest accrued thereon prior to
the due date for deposits as provided in this subsection. The remainder of such
monies shall be forwarded quarterly by the court clerk to the state treasury.
Deposits shall be due July 15 for the preceding quarter ending June 30, October
15 for the preceding quarter ending September 30, January 15 for the preceding
quarter ending December 31, and April 15 for the preceding quarter ending March
31. (1980 Code § 12-32; amd. 2002 Code)
1-10-26: PAYMENT OF JAIL COSTS BY INMATE:
   A.   The city court shall require a person who is actually received in
custody at the jail facility or who is confined in the city jail or holding
facility for any offense, to pay the jail facility or holding facility the
costs of incarceration, both before and after conviction, upon conviction, or
receiving a deferred sentence. The costs of incarceration shall be collected by
the clerk of the court as provided for collection of other costs and fines,
which shall be subject to review under procedures set forth in section VIII of
the rules of the Oklahoma court of criminal appeals, chapter 18, appendix of
title 22 of the Oklahoma Statutes. Costs of incarceration shall include
booking, receiving and processing out, housing, food, clothing, medical care,
dental care and psychiatric services. The costs for incarceration shall be an
amount equal to the actual cost of the services and shall be determined by the
chief of police for the city jails and holding facilities, or by contract
amount, if applicable. The operations cost for prisoners who are jailed for
more than twenty four (24) hours shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00) per day. In
the event a person requires emergency medical treatment for an injury or
condition that threatens life or threatens loss or use of a limb prior to being
actually received into the custody of any jail facility, the provisions of
section 533 of title 21 of the Oklahoma Statutes shall apply to taking custody,
medical care and cost responsibility. The court shall order the defendant to
reimburse all actual costs of incarceration, upon conviction or upon entry of a
deferred judgment and sentence unless the defendant is a mentally ill person as
defined by section 1-103 of title 43A of the Oklahoma Statutes. The Drumright
police department shall give notice to the defendant of the actual costs owed
before any court ordered costs are collected. The defendant shall have an
opportunity to object to the amount of costs solely on the grounds that the
number of days served is incorrect. If no objection is made, the costs may be
collected in the amount stated in the notice to the defendant. When the
municipality or other public entity responsible for the operation of the jail
collects any court ordered incarceration costs from the inmate or by criminal
or civil action, the court clerk shall be notified of the amount collected.
   B.   Except as may otherwise be provided in section 533 of title 21 of the
Oklahoma Statutes, any offender receiving routine or emergency medical services
or medications or injured during commission of a felony or misdemeanor offense
and administered any medical care shall be required to reimburse the Drumright
police department, city of Drumright or other public entity responsible for the
operation of the jail, the full amount paid by the Drumright police department,
city of Drumright or other public entity responsible for the operation of the
jail for any medical care or treatment administered to such offender during any
period of incarceration or when the person was actually received into custody
for any reason in that jail facility. The Drumright police department, city of
Drumright or other public entity responsible for the operation of the jail may
deduct the costs of medical care and treatment as authorized by section 531 of
title 19 of the Oklahoma Statutes. If the funds collected from the jail account
of the inmate does not have sufficient funds to satisfy the actual medical
costs paid, the Drumright police department, city of Drumright or other public
entity responsible for the operation of the jail shall be authorized to collect
the remaining balance of the medical care and treatment by civil actions.
   C.   Costs of incarceration shall be a debt of the inmate owed to the city
of Drumright or other public entity responsible for the operation of the jail
and may be collected as provided by law for collection of any other civil debt
or criminal penalty.
   D.   The court shall not waive the costs of incarceration in their entirety.
However, if the court determines that the reduction in the fine, costs, and
costs of incarceration is warranted, the court shall equally apply the same
percentage reduction to the fine, costs and costs of incarceration owed by the
defendant. (Ord. 272, 1-11-2010)
TITLE 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
CHAPTER 1
PLANNING AND ZONING BOARD
SECTION:
2-1-1: Planning And Zoning Board Created; Members
2-1-2: Organization, Rules Of Procedure, Quorum, Authority
2-1-3: Planning And Zoning Board Functions, Fees
2-1-1: PLANNING AND ZONING BOARD CREATED; MEMBERS:
   A.   Composition, Terms Of Office, Compensation:
      1.   There is hereby created a planning and zoning board for the city of
Drumright which shall consist of five (5) members as follows: one member shall
be a member of the city commission who shall be appointed for his or her term
of office as a city commissioner, one member shall be the city manager, one
member shall be the chief building official/code enforcement officer, one
member shall be the chief of police and one member shall be any qualified
citizen who is a resident of the city. The mayor shall appoint the city
commissioner and the resident citizen and they shall be approved by a majority
vote of the city commission.
      2.   The members shall serve without compensation except for
reimbursement of expenses incurred in the performance of their duties.
      3.   The citizen resident shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years,
concurrent with the term of the mayor. The city manager, chief building
official/code enforcement officer and police chief shall be permanent members
by virtue of their positions and shall cease to serve upon relinquishment of
their positions. As stated above, the city commissioner shall serve during the
term of his or her office. (Ord. 281, 11-8-2010)
2-1-2: ORGANIZATION, RULES OF PROCEDURE, QUORUM, AUTHORITY:
   A.   Officers: The city commission member appointed to the planning and
zoning board shall serve as chairman. The resident citizen shall serve as vice
chairman. The city clerk shall be the secretary of the board but shall not be a
voting member of the board.
   B.   Rules Of Procedure: The board shall generally follow the procedures
prescribed by "Robert's Rules Of Order", but may make exceptions thereto. All
votes shall be recorded individually by "yeas" having an affirmative meaning
and "nays" having a negative meaning. All votes shall require a majority
affirmative vote of those present and voting for adoption.
   C.   Quorum: In order to conduct any business, a quorum or three (3) members
must be present at a meeting.
   D.   Authority: The planning and zoning board may consider and investigate
any matter pertaining to the development and betterment of the city but its
sole power is to make recommendations to the city commission concerning the
advisability of adopting any zoning change, plat map adoption, new street
construction, street names on new streets, and similar things. (Ord. 281, 11-8-
2010)
2-1-3: PLANNING AND ZONING BOARD FUNCTIONS, FEES:
   A.   All plans, plats or replats of land laid out in lots or plats and
streets, alleys or other portions of land intended to be dedicated to public
use within the corporate limits of the city and all requests for zoning map
amendments or variances therefrom shall be first submitted to said planning and
zoning board for its review and recommendation to the city commission for
approval or denial. Upon the receipt of a request for a zoning map amendment,
the planning and zoning board shall call a meeting, in accordance with the
Oklahoma open meeting statutes, post the agenda and proceed to meet. The board
shall adopt its recommendation and forward it to the city commission at its
next following regular meeting.
   B.   The planning and zoning board may, on its own initiative, recommend
amendments to the Drumright zoning map.
   C.   Applicants for a change in zoning classification shall pay a fee of
forty dollars ($40.00) plus the costs of any publication charges which shall be
deposited in the general fund of the city prior to calling a meeting to act
upon the application. (Ord. 281, 11-8-2010)
CHAPTER 2
BOARD OF PUBLIC PARKS AND CEMETERIES
(Rep. by Ord. 282, 11-8-2010)
CHAPTER 3
LIBRARY BOARD AND THE LIBRARY
SECTION:
2-3-1: Library Board Established; Board Appointments; Terms
2-3-2: Organization; Powers And Duties
2-3-3: Librarian
2-3-4: Financial
2-3-1: LIBRARY BOARD ESTABLISHED; BOARD APPOINTMENTS; TERMS:
There is hereby established a Drumright public library board consisting of five
(5) members. The library board shall recommend to the city commission policies
and procedures for the governance of the Drumright public library. The mayor
shall appoint members of the board and the city commission shall confirm the
appointments prior to the board members entering office. Board members shall be
appointed based on their interest in the library, their individual education
and areas of expertise. Board members shall initially serve terms as follows:
position 1, one year, positions 2 and 3, two (2) years and positions 4 and 5,
three (3) years. Upon completion of these initial terms, all positions shall be
appointed for three (3) year terms. Board members may serve for up to twelve
(12) years total, but the city commission may make exceptions if no other
qualified persons agree to serve on the board. Vacancies on the board may be
filled for the remainder of a term of the person who vacates a position on the
board. (Ord. 278, 8-9-2010)
2-3-2: ORGANIZATION; POWERS AND DUTIES:
The board members shall organize and adopt their own rules of procedure and
they may adopt bylaws for their own guidance. They may adopt recommendations
for policies and procedures, acquisitions and disposals of materials and other
matters pertaining to the Drumright public library but any such recommendations
must be approved by the city commission before taking effect. The board may
establish policies related to fines for overdue materials on loan, rentals and
penalties for failure to adhere to library policies and failure to return
materials. (Ord. 278, 8-9-2010)
2-3-3: LIBRARIAN:
There shall be a library director who shall be appointed by and be under the
supervision of the city manager. The library director shall be an advisor to
the library board. The board shall not direct the work of the library director
or the director's subordinate employees. (Ord. 278, 8-9-2010)
2-3-4: FINANCIAL:
All money collected by the library shall be remitted to the city clerk to be
deposited into the general fund of the city of Drumright. All purchases made by
the library director on behalf of the library shall be processed in the same
manner as any other claim against the city of Drumright. (Ord. 278, 8-9-2010)
CHAPTER 4
CIVIL DEFENSE ORGANIZATION
SECTION:
2-4-1: Organization Created; General Duties
2-4-2: Director And Advisory Committee Appointments
2-4-3: Powers And Duties Of Director
2-4-4: Enforcement Powers
2-4-5: Compensation; Nonliability Of City
2-4-1: ORGANIZATION CREATED; GENERAL DUTIES:
The purpose of this chapter is to create a civil defense organization for the
city to be prepared for, and to function in the event of, emergencies
endangering the lives and property of the people of the city. The duty of such
civil defense organization shall be the protection of the lives and health of
the citizens of Drumright, and of property and property rights, both private
and public, and to perform all functions necessary and incident thereto. (1980
Code § 1-95)
2-4-2: DIRECTOR AND ADVISORY COMMITTEE APPOINTMENTS:
There is hereby established under the executive branch of the government of the
city a department of civil defense which shall consist of:
   A.   Appointment: A director of civil defense who shall be appointed by the
mayor, with the approval of the board of commissioners, and serve at his
pleasure.
   B.   Civil Defense Advisory Committee: This committee shall consist of the
mayor, as chairman, and four (4) members, one of whom shall be the director of
civil defense, appointed by the mayor and serving at his pleasure. The
committee shall select from its members, a vice chairman and secretary. It
shall hold such meetings as are directed by the mayor and its function shall be
to act in an advisory capacity as needed or requested by the mayor or the
director of civil defense. (1980 Code § 1-96; amd. 2002 Code)
2-4-3: POWERS AND DUTIES OF DIRECTOR:
   A.   General Duties And Authority; Compensation:
      1.   The director of civil defense shall be the executive head of the
department of civil defense and shall be responsible for carrying out the civil
defense program of the city.
      2.   He shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for
expenses incurred in the performance of his duties.
      3.   It shall be the duty of the director of civil defense, as soon as
practicable after his appointment, to perfect an organization to carry out the
purposes set forth in this chapter, and he shall have all necessary power and
authority to form committees or other bodies and to appoint and designate the
chairman or chief of such bodies as may be necessary to perfect such an
organization.
      4.   He shall have the further duty and responsibility to cooperate with
all civil defense agencies of other governmental units including the state of
Oklahoma and the federal government. (1980 Code § 1-97)
   B.   Formulate Plans; Gather Information: The director of civil defense is
further authorized to formulate written plans and gather information and keep
written record thereof to govern the functions of the civil defense
organization. (1980 Code § 1-98)
   C.   Emergency Situations: In the event of an enemy caused emergency or
emergency resulting from natural causes, the director of civil defense, after
due authorization from the mayor and acting under his instructions, shall have
the power and authority to enforce all rules and regulations relating to civil
defense and, if necessary, take control of transportation, communications,
stocks of fuel, food, clothing, medicine, and public utilities for the purpose
of protecting the civilian population. He shall cooperate in every way with the
activities of other governmental agencies or civil defense organizations; and,
if required by the mayor, shall have control over any and all funds allocated
from any source for the purpose of alleviating distress conditions in the city.
(1980 Code § 1-99)
2-4-4: ENFORCEMENT POWERS:
The director of civil defense and other members of the civil defense
organization created by him shall have the power and authority to enforce the
laws of the state and ordinances of the city during the period of emergency and
shall at such time have the further power to make arrests the same as a duly
constituted peace officer for violations of such laws and ordinances. (1980
Code § 1-100)
2-4-5: COMPENSATION; NONLIABILITY OF CITY:
All members of the civil defense organization created herein shall serve
without compensation, and the city shall not be liable for any personal injury
received by any member of such organization while acting in the line of duty.
(1980 Code § 1-101)
CHAPTER 5
POLICE PENSION AND RETIREMENT FUND BOARD OF TRUSTEES
(Rep. by Ord. 270, 12-14-2009)
CHAPTER 6
INDUSTRIAL AUTHORITY
SECTION:

2-6-3: Powers And Duties; Trust Indenture
2-6-1: AUTHORITY CREATED:
There is hereby established and created the Drumright industrial authority.
(1980 Code § 7-36)
2-6-2: MEMBERSHIP; QUALIFICATIONS:
The authority shall be composed of five (5) members, who shall be residents of
the city, or the surrounding community. (1980 Code § 7-37)
2-6-3: POWERS AND DUTIES; TRUST INDENTURE:
   A.   Compliance With Agreement: The duration, duties, trust estate,
trustees, powers and duties of the trustees, beneficiary of the trust, and
termination of trust shall be in accordance with the revised and amended trust
indenture agreement, dated March 12, 2012, which instrument is referred to,

   B.   Beneficial Interest Accepted: The terms of said revised and amended
trust indenture agreement, dated March 12, 2012, are hereby accepted. (Ord.
303, 11-12-2013)

GAS AUTHORITY
SECTION:

2-7-1: BENEFICIAL INTEREST ACCEPTED:
The trust indenture by and between Cleo J. Hutchinson as trustor, and Cleo J.
