public view and out of reach of the driver or any occupant of the vehicle.
(1980 Code § 2-22)
3-3B-10: DRINKING IN PUBLIC; INTOXICATED PERSONS:
Drinking and Intoxication in Public: No person within the city shall drink
intoxicating liquor in any public place, nor shall any person be intoxicated in
a public place within the city. (1980 Code § 2-23) An exception to drinking in
public is Farmers Markets and other events when they are registered with the
Oklahoma Department of Agriculture, Food and Forestry as a trade show, which
therefore allows for the sale of alcohol at the market. Registered wineries are
allowed to give free samples and to sell by the glass. However, per state
statutes and/or the Able Commission, the entire market becomes the tasting room
and therefore it is the responsibility of the wineries to monitor all alcohol
consumption whether from their winery or not while on the premise. If a
compliance check is done and someone underage is served, every winery will be
ticketed since it is a shared space. Alcohol cannot leave the market;
therefore, wineries can sell by the glass to be consumed at the market, but
bottles must be taken home to be consumed. (Ord. 338, 5-10-2021)
3-3B-11: DAYS AND HOURS OF OPERATION:
   A.   Days And Hours: No person shall open for business or keep open for
business, or sell or deliver alcoholic beverages to any person at a retail
alcoholic beverage store in the city on any Sunday, New Year's Day, Memorial
Day, Fourth of July, Labor Day, Veterans Day, Thanksgiving Day, or Christmas
Day, or, while the polls are open on the day of any general, primary, run off
primary, or special election, whether national, state, county, or city, or on
any other day except between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. and nine
o'clock (9:00) P.M. (1980 Code § 2-26)
   B.   Wholesalers Selling To Retailers On Certain Days: No wholesale dealer
in alcoholic beverages, and no officer, agent, or employee of such a dealer,
shall sell or deliver to any retail alcoholic beverage store in the city any
amount of spirits or wines on Saturday of any week, Sunday of any week, New
Year's Day, Memorial Day, Fourth of July, Labor Day, Veterans Day, Thanksgiving
Day, or Christmas Day, or, while the polls are open on the day of any general,
primary, run off primary, or special election, whether national, state, county,
or city. (1980 Code § 2-31)
3-3B-12: SALES ON CREDIT:
No person, at any retail alcoholic beverage store in the city, shall sell any
alcoholic beverage on credit, except as authorized by state law. (1980 Code §
2-27)
3-3B-13: OFFERING PRIZES OR GIFTS:
No owner or proprietor of a retail alcoholic beverage store, and no person
employed therein, shall offer or furnish any prize, premium, gift, or similar
inducement to a consumer in connection with a sale of alcoholic beverage. (1980
Code § 2-28)
3-3B-14: PENALTY:
   A.   Penalty Imposed: Any violation of any of the provisions of this article
is an offense against the city and, upon conviction of such offense, the
violator shall be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (1980 Code § 2-34; amd. 2002 Code)
   B.   Separate Offense For Each Day: As to any violation of any provision of
this article which consists in the maintenance of physical condition of
premises or of physical structures, each day's violation shall constitute a
separate offense. (1980 Code § 2-33)
ARTICLE C. LOW POINT BEER
SECTION:
3-3C-1: Definitions
3-3C-2: Licenses And Permits Required
3-3C-3: License Fees
3-3C-4: Sell Or Furnish To Minors
3-3C-5: Hours Of Sale Restricted
3-3C-6: Intoxicated Persons
3-3C-7: Gambling
3-3C-8: Open View Of Premises
3-3C-9: Public Nuisance; Abatement
3-3C-10: Penalty
3-3C-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed
to them in this section:
BEER PARLOR: Any place in the city of Drumright where "low point beer", as
herein defined, is sold, distributed, or dispensed for consumption on the
premises.
LOW POINT BEER: All beverages containing more than one-half of one percent
(0.5%) alcohol by volume, and not more than three and two-tenths percent (3.2%)
alcohol by weight.
RETAIL BEER PARLOR DEALER: Any and all persons, firms, corporations,
associations or concessionaires who sell, distribute or dispense any "low point
beer" as herein defined, from a "beer parlor" as herein defined.
RETAIL DEALER: All persons, firms, corporations, associations or
concessionaires who sell, distribute or dispense any "low point beer", as
herein defined, within the corporate limits of the city of Drumright, without
regard to the place where such beverages may be consumed or used.
RETAIL PACKAGE DEALER: Any and all persons, firms, corporations, associations,
or concessionaires who sell, distribute or dispense any "low point beer", as
herein defined, in original packages and not for consumption on the premises of
the dealer. (1980 Code § 2-63; amd. 2002 Code)
3-3C-2: LICENSES AND PERMITS REQUIRED:
   A.   City License: It shall be unlawful and an offense for any retail
dealer, whether permanent or temporary, at any place within the incorporated
limits of the city, to sell, distribute or dispense any low point beer without
having first applied for and received a city license as herein required. (1980
Code § 2-72; amd. 2002 Code)
   B.   State And County Permits Prerequisite: No city license shall be issued
to any retail dealer by the city clerk without a satisfactory showing that the
applicant has obtained all state and county permits required by law, and has in
all other respects complied with the laws of Oklahoma relating to the sale and
distribution of low point beer. (1980 Code § 2-73; amd. 2002 Code)
3-3C-3: LICENSE FEES:
   A.   Fees Imposed: From and after the adoption and effective date hereof,
there shall be levied the following annual city license fees:
      1.   Each retail dealer in "low point beer", as herein defined, for
consumption on and off the premises, twenty dollars ($20.00) per year.
      2.   Each retail dealer in low point beer in original packages and not
for consumption on the premises, ten dollars ($10.00) per year. (1980 Code § 2-
71; amd. 2002 Code)
   B.   Payment Of Fee: All such city license fees shall be paid to the city
clerk at the time of issuance of such licenses by the city clerk, and in the
manner prescribed herein.
   C.   Term Of License; Prorate Fee: In this connection, in the issuance of
such license, said license shall be issued to expire June 30 next after such
issuance. The amount of such license fee shall be prorated to the nearest month
then expired in that fiscal year.
   D.   License Nontransferable: The licenses herein provided for are not
transferable either to another retail dealer or for a different location in the
city. (1980 Code § 2-71)
3-3C-4: SELL OR FURNISH TO MINORS:
It shall be unlawful and an offense for any retail dealer, his or its agents,
servants or employees to sell, barter, offer for sale, or to give away to any
minor person any low point beer for use either upon or off the premises of such
retail dealer. (1980 Code § 2-64; amd. 2002 Code)
3-3C-5: HOURS OF SALE RESTRICTED:
It shall be unlawful and an offense for any retail dealer of a beer parlor, his
or its agents, servants or employees, to sell or offer for sale or to give away
at such beer parlor, any low point beer for consumption on the premises,
between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. Sunday and twelve o'clock (12:00)
noon Sunday. (Ord. 232, 11-6-2001; amd. 2002 Code)
3-3C-6: INTOXICATED PERSONS:
   A.   Sales To: It shall be unlawful and an offense for any retail dealer,
his or its agents, servants or employees to sell, barter, or dispense to any
intoxicated person any low point beer. (1980 Code § 2-66; amd. 2002 Code)
   B.   Dealer Intoxicated: It shall be unlawful and an offense for any retail
dealer, his or its agents or employees to sell, barter or dispense any low
point beer while such seller or dispenser of same is intoxicated. (1980 Code §
2-67; amd. 2002 Code)
   C.   Loitering By Intoxicated Persons: It shall be unlawful and an offense
for any retail dealer, his or its agents, servants or employees to permit or
allow any intoxicated person to loiter in or around a beer parlor or place of
business. (1980 Code § 2-68)
3-3C-7: GAMBLING:
It shall be unlawful and an offense for any retail dealer, his or its agents,
servants, or employees in the conduct and operation of a beer parlor, or a
place of business where low point beer is bartered or sold, to violate or
permit the violation therein of what is commonly known as the "gambling laws"
of the state, or criminal ordinances of the city. (1980 Code § 2-69; amd. 2002
Code)
3-3C-8: OPEN VIEW OF PREMISES:
   A.   View From Outside Premises: It shall be unlawful and an offense for any
retail dealer, his or its agents, servants or employees, in the operation of a
beer parlor, to barter, sell or dispense therein low point beer if the outer
doors or windows at the time are screened from public view from the street or
sidewalk by any curtain, shade, painting of windows or doors, or by partition
or otherwise, so as to screen from public view the customers of said beer
parlor.
   B.   License Withheld For Violation: No license shall be issued for a beer
parlor if screened in violation hereof. (1980 Code § 2-70; amd. 2002 Code)
3-3C-9: PUBLIC NUISANCE; ABATEMENT:
The conduct of any beer parlor in violation of the terms and provisions of this
article is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and the proper officers of
the city, on resolution of the city commission, may summarily abate the same,
or may do the same by suit in the district court of Creek County, as provided
by 50 Oklahoma Statutes sections 16 and 17. (1980 Code § 2-75)
3-3C-10: PENALTY:
Any person, firm, or corporation who violates any provision of this article
shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction therefor, shall be subject
to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. Each day that such violation continues or is permitted to
continue shall constitute a separate offense. (1980 Code § 2-76; amd. 2002
Code)
CHAPTER 4
ENTERTAINMENTS; SHOWS
ARTICLE A. DEVICES AND SHOWS ON STREETS 1
SECTION:
3-4A-1: License Required
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-1-12 of this title for penalty provisions.
3-4A-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   A.   Devices On Streets: It is unlawful and an offense for any person,
without a license therefor, to maintain or construct any cane rack, doll rack,
knife board, shooting gallery, wheel of fortune, or any other such device upon
any of the streets or alleys of the city. (1980 Code § 5-12)
   B.   Shows On Streets: It is hereby made unlawful and an offense for any
person, not having a license therefor, to maintain or exhibit any circus show
or animal show, or to give any concert or show for profit, upon any street or
alley of the city. (1980 Code § 5-13)
ARTICLE B. BILLIARDS, POOL AND BOWLING 1
SECTION:
3-4B-1: Pool And Billiard Halls; License Required
3-4B-2: Public Nuisances Enumerated
3-4B-3: Bowling Alleys
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-1-12 of this title for penalty provisions.
3-4B-1: POOL AND BILLIARD HALLS; LICENSE REQUIRED:
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to operate any pool or billiard
hall, room, place or table for a consideration of any kind without first having
obtained a license as provided by this article. (1980 Code § 5-38)
3-4B-2: PUBLIC NUISANCES ENUMERATED:
All billiard halls, pool rooms or other places where any billiard, pool or
combination billiard and pool table or tables are or may be kept or operated
for hire shall be deemed public nuisances under any one of the following
circumstances, with or without a license:
   A.   Gambling; Betting Or Lottery:
      1.   When any slot machine, game of chance or any betting is permitted in
or operated in such hall, room or place.
      2.   When any gambling, game of chance or any betting is permitted or
carried on in such hall, room or place.
      3.   When any lottery is conducted, carried on or permitted in such hall,
room or place.
   B.   Prizefights: When any prizefight, boxing contest, wrestling match,
fistic encounter, fight or other contest of physical strength is carried on or
permitted in such hall, room or place.
   C.   Disorderly Conduct:
      1.   When any disorderly conduct or practice is permitted in such hall,
room or place.
      2.   When any disturbance or disorderly assembly is permitted in such
hall, room, or place.
   D.   Intoxicating Liquor:
      1.   When any intoxicating liquors are bartered, sold, given away or
otherwise furnished or the same permitted to be done in such hall, room or
place.
      2.   When the drinking of alcoholic beverages is permitted in such hall,
room or place.
      3.   When any alcoholic beverages are bartered, sold, given away or
otherwise furnished or the same permitted to be done in such hall, room, or
place.
   E.   Noise; Profanity: When any loud, boisterous or unusual noise or profane
or vulgar language is permitted in such hall, room or place.
   F.   Immoral Or Indecent Shows: When any immoral or indecent show or
exhibition is permitted in such hall, room or place.
   G.   Character And Reputation: When any person or persons of bad character
and reputation are permitted to loaf or loiter in and about such hall, room or
place.
   H.   Days And Hours Of Operation:
      1.   Sundays: When such hall, room or place is opened or permitted to be
opened on the Sabbath day commonly called Sunday, except from one o'clock (1:
00) P.M. until eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. thereof.
      2.   Closing Time: When such hall, room or place is permitted to remain
open later than twelve thirty o'clock (12:30) A.M. any night, except as
provided in subsection H1 of this section.
   I.   Minors: When any minor under the age of eighteen (18) years is
permitted to enter or be in such hall, room or place; except properly
supervised recreation centers.
   J.   Annoying, Endangering Others: When anything which annoys, injures or
endangers the comfort, repose, health or safety of others is permitted or
carried on in such hall, room or place. (1980 Code § 5-36; amd. 2002 Code)
3-4B-3: BOWLING ALLEYS:
All bowling alleys shall be subject to the same regulations, penalty and manner
of abatement as in section
3-4B-2 of this article, provided for billiard and pool halls, except that
bowling alleys may remain open on Sundays between the hours of one o'clock (1:
00) P.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. (1980 Code § 5-37)
ARTICLE C. DANCE HALLS 1
SECTION:
3-4C-1: Definition; Application Of Provisions
3-4C-2: Persons Liable
3-4C-3: Licensing Requirements
3-4C-4: Police Attendance Required
3-4C-5: Location Restrictions
3-4C-6: Operating Requirements And Restrictions
3-4C-7: Minors
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-1-12 of this title for penalty provisions.
3-4C-1: DEFINITION; APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   Definition: The term "public dance hall" or "public ball", as used in
this article, shall be construed to mean any dance or ball to which admission
may be obtained:
      1.   By payment of a fee or by the purchase, possession, or presentation
of a ticket, token, or pass, for which a charge is made for the care of
clothing, for admission to the dance, or for dancing at the dance.
      2.   Any dance to which the public generally may obtain admission, with
or without the payment of a fee. The term "public dance hall" as used herein
shall be construed to mean any room, place or space in which a public dance or
public ball is held, or in which classes and instructions in dancing are given
for hire, together with all adjoining or connected rooms, halls, cloak rooms,
waiting rooms, rooms where drinks and refreshments are served, or other
appurtenances connected therewith to which customers of the dance have access.
   B.   Private Dances Excepted: The provisions of this article shall not be
construed in any way to apply to or interfere with private dances given at the
private homes of reputable people or to or with dances given by permanently
organized clubs, societies, or corporations, or to school or alumni dances
where the attendance is restricted to the members of the society, club or
corporation, or to the guests of the club, admitted by individual invitations
only.
   C.   Imposing Charges: Any club or organization, exacting fees or charges of
any kind or character from other than bona fide members, shall be subject to
all the provisions of this article. (1980 Code § 5-62)
3-4C-2: PERSONS LIABLE:
The owners of the premises, lessees of the premises where said public dance or
ball is being held, and all persons, firms and corporations, their agents,
servants, and employees conducting, or in any manner assisting in conducting
said public dance, including ticket sellers, ticket takers, persons conducting
or in charge of said public dance, and persons serving drinks and refreshments,
shall be considered as persons conducting said public dance, and they shall be
held jointly and severally liable, for any and all violations of the terms of
this article, and the terms of any ordinance of the city to which this article
refers or relates. (1980 Code § 5-63)
3-4C-3: LICENSING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   License Required; Exception: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm
or corporation, as set out in section
3-4C-2 of this article, to conduct, operate, or in any manner aid or supervise
any public dance in any capacity, or to hold or to conduct classes in dancing
or to give instructions in dancing in any public dance hall, unless and until
such person, firm or corporation shall have first been licensed for such
purpose; provided, that this section shall not apply to dancing instructions
given to members of a class in a private residence, or place other than a
public dance hall.
   B.   Application For License: Application to conduct a dance or public ball
shall be made in writing to the city clerk, on forms furnished by the city
clerk. The applicant must give his, her, its or their names and addresses, the
street number of the place where the dance or dancing instructions will be
conducted and the day or night such public dance or dancing instructions are to
be given. (1980 Code § 5-64; amd. 2002 Code)
   C.   Denial Of License: No license or permit shall be granted to any person,
firm or corporation whose license has been revoked by the city commission, or
for a place which has been adjudged a public nuisance, at any time within the
next preceding twelve (12) months.
   D.   Application Conditions:
      1.   Assistants Listed: Said application shall show the names and
addresses of all persons who will assist in any way in the conduct of said
public dance, either as ticket takers, hat checkers, door keepers, floor
leaders or persons serving drinks and refreshments; and no license or permit
will be issued if any of such persons do not bear a reputation for sobriety,
and for abiding by the laws of the state and city.
      2.   Time For Filing Application: Applications must be filed on or before
five o'clock (5:00) P.M. of the day preceding the day of the dance.
   E.   Refusal Of License: The city clerk must refuse a permit or license
hereunder if, at any time within twelve (12) months preceding the date of the
application, the previous holder of a license or permit hereunder, or any of
its agents, servants or employees have failed to conduct a public dance at such
location, in all respects as required by this, or any other ordinance of the
city, or who have failed during said period of time to give full and complete
cooperation with the city police in the supervision of said public dance, and
bringing to trial any person charged with the commission of a crime in said
public dance hall.
   F.   Qualified Applicant: The only qualified applicant for such permit shall
be either the owner of said premises, or a lessee holding a valid written lease
thereon, through their duly qualified agents and authorized representatives.
(1980 Code § 5-64)
3-4C-4: POLICE ATTENDANCE REQUIRED:
No "public dance", as defined herein, shall be held in the city without the
attendance thereat of a special or regular police officer at all hours of the
dance, to be designated and appointed by the city manager, which said officer
shall receive compensation in such amount as the city clerk is directed to pay
and turn over to said police officer for his services, and take his receipt
therefor. (1980 Code § 5-65; amd. 2002 Code)
3-4C-5: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Residence District: No license or permit shall be issued for a place in
a residence district, where fifty percent (50%) or more of the heads of
families residing within three hundred feet (300') of such dance hall shall
object by petition in writing to the city commission. Provided, that this
subsection shall not apply to any dance hall that has been established at, or
prior to, the time of the effective date hereof. (1980 Code § 5-66)
   B.   Near Church Or School: No license for a public dance shall be granted
where the place in which it is to be held is within three hundred feet (300')
of a church or public school. (1980 Code § 5-67)
3-4C-6: OPERATING REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS 1 :
   A.   Closing Time: All public dances and all dance halls shall be closed on
or before twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight.
   B.   Prohibited On Sunday: No public dance or public ball shall be conducted
on Sunday.
   C.   Ticket Taker On Duty: A minimum of one doorkeeper or ticket taker shall
remain on duty until the closing hour.
   D.   Payment Of Admission Fee Required; Exception: Admission to persons who
have not paid an admission fee, except the manager, employees and musicians on
duty, shall not be allowed. (1980 Code § 5-68)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 5-1B-8 of this code.
3-4C-7: MINORS:
It shall be unlawful for any proprietor, or person in charge of any public
dance or public ball to permit, or suffer any person under the age of eighteen
(18) years to take part in any dance or attend the same, unless such person be
in company with, and attended by a parent or legal guardian. (1980 Code § 5-69)
ARTICLE D. AMUSEMENT CENTERS 1
SECTION:
3-4D-1: Family Amusement Center Defined
3-4D-2: Permitted Establishments
3-4D-3: Application For License; Denial; Appeal
3-4D-4: License Fee
3-4D-5: Conditions Of Operation; Hours
3-4D-6: Coin Operated Machines; Billiard Tables
3-4D-7: Suspension Or Revocation Of License
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-1-12 of this title for penalty provisions.
3-4D-1: FAMILY AMUSEMENT CENTER DEFINED:
A "family amusement center" is defined by this article as a room or place where
persons may gather jointly or separately to play games that are kept or
operated there for gain or profit. "Games" are defined to mean any game or
sport which is done solely for the enjoyment derived from the game itself and
does not involve gambling or other illegal activities. The term "games" shall
include the games of pool, snooker, and billiards, which may be coin operated
and shall also include any other coin operated amusement devices. A room or
place in which are located more than two (2) such tables or games shall be
considered a "family amusement center". (1980 Code § 5-71; amd. 2002 Code)
3-4D-2: PERMITTED ESTABLISHMENTS:
The establishment and operation of family amusement centers in the city is
authorized and permitted with the passage of this article and subject to the
regulations herein contained. (1980 Code § 5-70)
3-4D-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; DENIAL; APPEAL:
   A.   Application: Application for license to be issued hereunder shall be
made upon forms prepared and made available by the chief of police or city
manager, and must be answered fully before such license shall be issued.
   B.   Investigation: Upon receipt of an application for license, the chief of
police shall promptly cause an investigation to be made of the applicant, and
of the manner in which the applicant proposes to operate the facility.
   C.   Denial Of License: If the chief of police disapproves and denies the
application, he shall notify the applicant in writing within five (5) days
after the denial thereof, giving the reasons for the denial of the license.
   D.   Appeal:
      1.   Any person, firm, corporation or association whose application for
license is denied shall have the right to appeal to the city commission.
      2.   Written notice of the appeal must be made by the applicant to the
city manager within five (5) days following the receipt of denial thereof and
the city manager shall cause said appeal to be placed on the agenda of the next
regular meeting of the city commission at which time hearing shall be held
thereon. (1980 Code § 5-73)
3-4D-4: LICENSE FEE:
Following approval of application for license, the applicant shall purchase a
license from the city clerk for each location where such a center is operated.
The license fee for same is fixed at twenty five dollars ($25.00) per location
per year. The fee charged shall be for the remainder of the fiscal year of
payment of license fees and each fiscal year thereafter. (1980 Code § 5-75)
3-4D-5: CONDITIONS OF OPERATION; HOURS:
   A.   Activities Authorized: Family amusement centers may operate pool,
snooker, billiard tables, or any other coin operated game for a profit for the
use of all persons of all ages and either sex.
   B.   Liquor Prohibited: No beer or other forms of intoxicating liquor may be
sold or consumed on the premises.
   C.   Gambling Prohibited: No gambling or wagering of any kind shall be
permitted on the premises.
   D.   Days And Hours Of Operation: All such places of business shall close at
ten thirty o'clock (10:30) P.M. each night except Friday and Saturday, and not
open again until nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. the following morning, except that on
Sunday the same shall remain closed until twelve o'clock (12:00) noon and shall
close again at five o'clock (5:00) P.M. on Sunday. Same may remain open until
twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight on Friday and Saturday. (1980 Code § 5-72)
3-4D-6: COIN OPERATED MACHINES; BILLIARD TABLES:
   A.   Operating Coin Operated Machines At Other Locations: Any other local
place of business, other than a "family amusement center" as defined herein,
may operate not to exceed two (2) coin operated pool, snooker or billiard
tables, or combinations thereof, when the operation of the same are incidental
to some other principal business, without the necessity of the purchase of any
license for the location but subject to the regulation for fees as provided in
this code. (1980 Code § 5-76)
   B.   Fees For Pool, Snooker Or Billiard Tables:
      1.   The owners of the tables which are governed by the provisions of
this article shall pay an annual fee to the city, in addition to the annual
license fee provided above, the following sums:
 
Number Of Pool, Snooker Or Billiard Tables Fee
1 to 10                                    $ 50.00
11 to 20                                   90.00
21 to 50                                   125.00
More than 50                               150.00
 
      2.   License fees on all other amusement devices located in family
amusement centers shall be paid as set forth in this chapter. (1980 Code § 5-
77; amd. 2002 Code)
3-4D-7: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
   A.   Authority: A violation of any of the terms and provisions of any of the
sections of this article, with or without the knowledge of the owner, licensee
or person in charge of the premises at the time same occurred, shall be grounds
for a fifteen (15) day suspension or complete cancellation of the license
issued hereunder.
   B.   Notice: The city manager shall, upon learning of such violation, issue
notice to the licensee of the suspension or cancellation of said license.
   C.   Appeal:
      1.   Any person, firm, corporation or association whose license is
suspended or canceled shall have the right to appeal to the city commission.
      2.   Written notice of the appeal must be made by the applicant to the
city manager within five (5) days following the notification of suspension or
cancellation thereof and the city manager shall cause said appeal to be placed
on the agenda of the next regular meeting of the city commission at which time
hearing shall be held thereon. (1980 Code § 5-74)
CHAPTER 5
RESIDENTIAL SALES 1
SECTION:
3-5-1: Definitions
3-5-2: License Required; Fee
3-5-3: Application For License
3-5-4: Issuance Of License
3-5-5: Exemptions
3-5-6: Compliance Required
3-5-7: Restrictions On Conducting Sales
3-5-8: Revocation Of License
3-5-9: Separate Violations
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-1-12 of this title for penalty provisions.
3-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever used in this chapter, the following words and terms, unless otherwise
clearly indicated by the context, shall have the following meanings:
CITY CLERK: The city clerk of the city of Drumright, Creek and Payne Counties,
Oklahoma.
OFFENSE: Every, each and any act done in violation of the terms of this
chapter.
RESIDENTIAL SALE: Any offering to the public for sale, barter or exchange, of
goods, articles, wares, and merchandise of any character whatsoever which
occurs or is conducted in a building constructed for, or used and occupied as,
a private residence, whether single-family or multi-family, or from any garage,
carport or other structure appurtenant to any such building; and shall include,
without exclusion of other sales falling within this definition, all such
transactions or offerings at vendue commonly known and referred to as garage
sales, porch sales, room sales, backyard sales, front yard sales, yard sales,
or patio sales; provided however, that this definition shall not include
offerings of specific items through an advertisement particularly naming and
identifying each individual item which is to be sold. (1980 Code § 5-41)
3-5-2: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
   A.   Requirement; Advertising Restricted: It is unlawful and an offense for
any person to hold, conduct, engage in, or participate in any manner in a
residential sale without having first obtained a license, as required by this
chapter, and no person shall advertise or publicly announce in any way that a
residential sale of any kind will be held before such person has obtained a
license. (1980 Code § 5-45)
   B.   Separate License Required: A separate license shall be required for
each location at which a residential sale is to be held, and no location shall
be eligible for more than one license in any six (6) month period. (1980 Code §
5-46)
   C.   License Fee: The license fee shall be five dollars ($5.00) for each
such residential sale held. (Ord. 266, 12-14-2009)
3-5-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An applicant for a license shall furnish the city clerk the following
information:
   A.   Full name and address.
   B.   The location at which the proposed residential sale is to be held.
(1980 Code § 5-47)
   C.   The date or dates upon which the sale will be held.
   D.   An affidavit from the applicant to the effect that all goods to be sold
at the residential sale are owned by the applicant and have not been obtained
for the purpose of reselling the articles at said sale. (1980 Code § 5-47; amd.
Ord. 266, 12-14-2009)
3-5-4: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
The city clerk is authorized to issue a license for a residential sale for a
period not to exceed seven (7) consecutive days to any person applying therefor
and who otherwise complies with the requirements of this chapter. (1980 Code §
5-48)
3-5-5: EXEMPTIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to, or affect, the following
persons:
   A.   Persons acting pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent
jurisdiction.
   B.   Persons acting in accordance within their powers and duties as public
officials.
   C.   Duly licensed auctioneers selling at auctions. (1980 Code § 5-42)
3-5-6: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct a residential sale except in strict compliance with the
provisions of this chapter. (1980 Code § 5-44)
3-5-7: RESTRICTIONS ON CONDUCTING SALES:
   A.   Intervals Between Sales: It is unlawful and an offense for any person
to hold, conduct, engage in, or participate in any manner in a residential
sale, or to allow a residential sale to be held or conducted on premises under
his control or ownership more than one time within any three (3) month period
and for no longer than four (4) consecutive days at any one time.
   B.   Signs: There shall be not more than two (2) signs or other devices used
for the purpose of calling attention to the sale on the premises of the sale,
said signs or devices to be not more than eight (8) square feet in size on any
surface. All other signs placed at any other locations off the premises of the
sale must be placed on private property with the permission of the property
owner. No signs may be placed on city rights of way or property or on utility
poles at other locations within the city. Any such signs placed in violation of
this provision containing an address shall be prima facie evidence of a
violation and shall make the person responsible for the sale subject to a
citation for littering which shall be prosecuted in the Drumright municipal
court.
   C.   Display Of Goods: The sale area at any residential sale shall be
confined to the premises owned or occupied by the person or persons operating
the sale. In no event shall articles or goods be displayed on the city right of
way or displayed in such a manner as to constitute a distraction to persons who
may be driving on any adjacent street.
   D.   Food And Drink For Public Consumption Prohibited: Due to public health
requirements, in no event shall either food or drink be sold or furnished at or
in connection with a residential sale to, or for the benefit of any member of
the public attending such sale. (Ord. 266, 12-14-2009)
3-5-8: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Any license issued under this chapter may be revoked or any application for
issuance of a license may be refused by the city clerk in the event the
application submitted by the applicant, or license holder, contains any false,
fraudulent, or misleading statement. (1980 Code § 5-50)
3-5-9: SEPARATE VIOLATIONS:
Every article sold, every act performed, and every day a sale is conducted in
violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense.
(1980 Code § 5-55)
CHAPTER 6
PAWNBROKERS, SECONDHAND AND JUNK DEALERS 1
SECTION:
3-6-1: License Fee
3-6-2: Bond Required
3-6-3: Register; Information Required
3-6-4: Inspection By Police
3-6-5: Days And Hours Of Operation
3-6-6: Certain Sales Prohibited
3-6-7: Minors Restricted
3-6-8: Concealing Lost Property
3-6-9: Suspicious Circumstances To Prevent Sale
3-6-10: Forfeiture Of License; Violation An Offense
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-1-12 of this title for penalty provisions.
3-6-1: LICENSE FEE:
Pawnbrokers, secondhand dealers, junk dealers and every person engaged in the
business of receiving goods upon pledge or under chattel mortgages shall pay an
annual license fee of ten dollars ($10.00). Said license shall be issued by the
city clerk. (1980 Code § 5-25)
3-6-2: BOND REQUIRED:
   A.   Bond; Conditions: Every person hereafter applying for a license to
engage in or carry on the business of pawnbroker, secondhand dealer, junk
dealer and every person engaged in the business of receiving goods upon pledge
or under chattel mortgages shall, before such license is issued to him, enter
into a bond with the city with sureties approved by the city clerk, in the
penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), conditioned that said applicant
will strictly and faithfully observe all ordinances, regulations and
requirements of the city in relation to pawnbrokers, secondhand dealers and
persons engaged in the business of receiving goods upon pledge or under chattel
mortgages, or their business, and will pay all costs, fines and penalties
incurred on account of his failure or neglect and will pay all damages
resulting to any person by reason of his wrongfully taking, purchasing, or
receiving from a minor.
   B.   Filing With Clerk; Nonliability Of City: The bond shall be filed with
the city clerk and may be sued upon by any person damaged, as aforesaid, but in
no event shall the city be liable for the cost of such suit. (1980 Code § 5-26)
3-6-3: REGISTER; INFORMATION REQUIRED:
   A.   Registration Of Items; Other Information:
      1.   Every pawnbroker, secondhand dealer, junk dealer and every person
engaged in the business of receiving goods upon pledge or under chattel
mortgages shall keep at his place of business a register in which he shall
enter in writing a minute description of all property taken, purchased or
received by him, including any number that may be in or upon any article,
together with the time and the name and place of residence (giving street and
number, if within the city) of the person leaving said property, also the
amount paid for or loaned upon each article so taken, the interest charged, and
the time when the loan falls due; which register shall be kept clean and
legible.
      2.   He shall make such entry within one hour after the receipt or
purchase of such property.
   B.   Entries In Ink: Every entry shall be made in ink and shall not in any
manner be obliterated or erased.
   C.   Ticket Issued To Person: To the person negotiating or leaving such
property, he shall give a plainly written or printed ticket, having upon it a
full and perfect copy of all the entries required by ordinance to be kept in
such register, for which copy no charge shall be made.
   D.   Bill Of Sale For Certain Property: No person shall be required to
furnish such description of any property purchased from manufacturers or
wholesale dealers having an established place of business. But such goods must
be accompanied by a bill of sale or other written evidence of open and
legitimate purchase, and must be shown to any officer when demanded. (1980 Code
§ 5-27; amd. 2002 Code)
3-6-4: INSPECTION BY POLICE:
   A.   Register: Said register, so kept by said person, shall at all times be
kept open to the inspection of the chief of police and sheriff of Creek County,
or the deputy of either, any officer of the police force of the city, the city
attorney, the district attorney and anyone authorized in writing for that
purpose by the chief of the police force, which authority shall be exhibited to
the pawnbroker, secondhand dealer, junk dealer, or person engaged in the
business of receiving such property, as aforesaid. (1980 Code § 5-28; amd. 2002
Code)
   B.   Articles Purchased Or Pledged: Every dealer covered by this chapter
shall, upon request, show and exhibit to such person or officer for inspection
any article or articles purchased, taken or received by him, unless the time of
the pledge has expired and the goods sold and delivered to the purchaser. (1980
Code § 5-28)
3-6-5: DAYS AND HOURS OF OPERATION:
No pawnbroker or other dealer or person covered by this chapter shall purchase,
take or receive on deposit or from any person any article of property between
the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M., and all such
dealers shall remain closed all day on Sundays. (1980 Code § 5-29)
3-6-6: CERTAIN SALES PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful and an offense in the city for any junk dealer, foundry,
repair shop, pawnbroker, secondhand dealer or for any person whomsoever, to
purchase, take or receive in pledge, by gift or on deposit, or to accept
possession of any article of property of, or from, any common drunkard, from
any person under the influence of intoxicating liquors or drugs, from any
person who is an habitual user of drugs of any kind, from any person who is
commonly known to be a "police court character", or from any person who has
previously been convicted of petty larceny. (1980 Code § 5-30)
3-6-7: MINORS RESTRICTED:
It shall be unlawful and an offense in the city for any person in charge of any
junk shop, secondhand store, pawnshop, or otherwise to purchase from or advance
money to any minor, under the age of eighteen (18) years, upon any things or
articles of value, or have any dealings respecting the title of property in the
possession of a minor without the written consent of the parents or guardian of
such minor, which shall be kept on file and subject to police inspection. (1980
Code § 5-31; amd. 2002 Code)
3-6-8: CONCEALING LOST PROPERTY:
Any person who shall attempt to conceal any stray or lost goods found or taken
up by him or shall efface any marks or brands thereon, or carry the same beyond
the limits of the city, or knowingly permit the same to be done, or shall
wilfully fail to cause the same to be advertised, sold or otherwise dealt with
as provided by the ordinances of the city, shall be deemed guilty of an
offense. (1980 Code § 5-32)
3-6-9: SUSPICIOUS CIRCUMSTANCES TO PREVENT SALE:
Any suspicious circumstances, or circumstances sufficient to put any ordinarily
prudent person upon his guard, shall be sufficient notice to any person to whom
property shall be offered for gift, sale, mortgage or pledge, to prohibit them
from accepting same; and any knowledge, notice, or information, as to the
improper character of the person offering same must prevent such sale, gift,
mortgage or pledge from being made until an investigation shall reveal that the
same may be lawfully made. The failure to exercise the precautions herein
prescribed, and the accepting of a gift, sale, mortgage or pledge of property
prohibited herein, which shall be stolen or shall be in the possession of one
not entitled thereto, which shall be disposed of by one not entitled or
competent to sell, pledge, mortgage or give away the same, shall be and
constitute an offense and be unlawful. (1980 Code § 5-33)
3-6-10: FORFEITURE OF LICENSE; VIOLATION AN OFFENSE:
   A.   Violation; Forfeit License: Any pawnbroker, junk dealer, secondhand
dealer, or any other person who may be engaged in any calling or occupation
which shall, under present or future ordinances of the city, require a license
or permit, who shall be guilty of the violation of any of the provisions of
this chapter, or who shall permit an employee or agent, in the course of such
employment or agency, to be guilty of the violation of any provision hereof,
shall in addition to the fine or imprisonment otherwise provided as a penalty
therefor, be, upon conviction, deprived of such license or permit; and upon
conviction, the clerk shall immediately revoke such license or permit.
   B.   Operation Without License Or Permit: Any person who shall operate or
engage in any business without first procuring a license and filing a bond as
herein provided shall be guilty of an offense, and each day's operation shall
constitute a separate offense. (1980 Code § 5-34)
CHAPTER 7
AUTOMOBILE SALVAGE ESTABLISHMENTS 1
SECTION:
3-7-1: Location Within City Unlawful
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-1-12 of this title for penalty provisions.
3-7-1: LOCATION WITHIN CITY UNLAWFUL:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to establish, maintain
or operate within the corporate limits of the city any automobile salvage, junk
or wrecking establishment. (1980 Code § 5-35; amd. 2002 Code)
CHAPTER 8
VEHICLES FOR HIRE
SECTION:
3-8-1: Definition
3-8-2: Registration Of Vehicles; Application
3-8-3: Vehicle Registration; Certificate Of Convenience And Necessity
3-8-4: License Fees
3-8-5: Public Liability Insurance
3-8-6: Inspection Of Vehicles
3-8-7: Cabstands Designated
3-8-8: Driver Drinking Liquor Or Intoxicated
3-8-9: Revocation Of License
3-8-10: Penalty
3-8-1: DEFINITION:
The term "motor vehicle" as used in this chapter shall be construed to mean any
and all motor vehicles used by any person, firm or corporation within the city
limits, for hire. (1980 Code § 21-1)
3-8-2: REGISTRATION OF VEHICLES; APPLICATION:
   A.   Registration: All motor vehicles offered to or used by the public for
hire within the city limits shall be registered with the city clerk. (1980 Code
§ 21-2)
   B.   Application: Any person, firm or corporation using a motor vehicle for
hire as mentioned in this chapter shall file his application in writing with
the city clerk, showing the name of the owner, the name of the operator of such
vehicle, the purpose for which such vehicle is offered to or used by the
public, and the serial number or engine number of each such motor vehicle, and
a description of such vehicle by make and model. (1980 Code § 21-3)
3-8-3: VEHICLE REGISTRATION; CERTIFICATE OF CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY:
   A.   Vehicle Registration:
      1.   Issuance By Clerk: When such application is filed, the city clerk
shall register such vehicle in a book to be kept by him for such purposes and
shall issue to the owner thereof a certificate showing such registration and
the purposes for which such motor vehicle is offered to the public for hire.
      2.   Display Of Registration In Vehicle: Such certificate shall be at all
times carried in such motor vehicle and displayed in a place visible by
passengers of such vehicle.
      3.   Transfer Allowed: Such certificate may be transferred from one
vehicle to another by the owner to whom the certificate was granted, upon
giving notice to the city clerk of such transfer, and by registering the serial
number or the motor number and description of the vehicle to which the
certificate is transferred. (1980 Code § 21-4)
   B.   Certificate Of Convenience And Necessity: Pursuant to 11 Oklahoma
Statutes section 22-118, the city may require the holding of a certificate of
convenience and necessity as a condition precedent to issuance of a city
license for the operation of a taxicab. (2002 Code)
3-8-4: LICENSE FEES:
At the time of registration of such motor vehicles and for the purpose of
defraying the expenses of police supervision, inspection and issuance of the
certificate herein provided for, the owner of each motor vehicle shall pay a
yearly license fee as provided for in section
3-1-8 of this title. Said payments shall be for the remainder of the fiscal
year of payment of license fees as provided in this chapter and there shall be
license fees for each year thereafter. (1980 Code § 21-9; amd. 2002 Code)
3-8-5: PUBLIC LIABILITY INSURANCE:
   A.   Operators: All owners and operators of motor vehicles for hire, as
herein designated, shall purchase, and have in full force and effect at all
times during which such motor vehicle or vehicles are operated within the city,
a policy of public liability insurance covering any person, firm or corporation
who might suffer injury or damage by reason of negligence of the owner or
operator of said motor vehicle or vehicles for hire, arising from the ownership
or operation thereof. Said public liability insurance shall be for the minimum
limits as set by motion or resolution of the city commission.
   B.   Taxicabs:
      1.   In addition, to subsection A of this section, all taxicabs shall be
required to carry minimum limit liability insurance coverage required to fully
comply with the financial responsibility laws of the state.
      2.   There shall be no maximum limits for the amount of such insurance
carried.
      3.   A certificate showing the above insurance coverage shall be
deposited with the city clerk for each vehicle operated for hire within the
city. (1980 Code § 21-8)
3-8-6: INSPECTION OF VEHICLES:
   A.   Certificate Of Inspection: Each motor vehicle shall be inspected at
least once every thirty (30) days by a competent mechanic and his certificate
of inspection shall be displayed in plain sight within said motor vehicle,
showing that brakes, tires, steering apparatus, horn and lights have been
inspected and found to be in good condition. Such certificate of inspection
shall be signed by the mechanic making the inspection and by the chief or
police every thirty (30) days.
   B.   Additional Inspection: The chief of police may require an additional
inspection by a competent mechanic of any such motor vehicle at any time he
deems it necessary. (1980 Code § 21-5)
3-8-7: CABSTANDS DESIGNATED:
No person, firm or corporation shall be permitted to use the parking areas of
the city in which to park said vehicles or from which to solicit business,
except in such places as the commission shall from time to time designate.
(1980 Code § 21-7)
3-8-8: DRIVER DRINKING LIQUOR OR INTOXICATED:
No person shall be permitted to operate such motor vehicle while under the
influence of intoxicating liquors, and for this purpose, the drinking of any
alcoholic beverage in any amount shall be construed and considered enough to
make such driver under the influence of intoxicating liquor. (1980 Code § 21-6)
3-8-9: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
If the operator of any such vehicle shall be convicted in any court within the
state for the violation of any law pertaining to the possession, use or sale of
intoxicating liquors while operating said motor vehicle, his permit to operate
said vehicle within the city, or any other vehicles for hire, shall immediately
and automatically be revoked, and he shall not be permitted to operate a
vehicle for hire within the city for a period of one year from that date.
Provided, that, upon two (2) such convictions, he shall not be permitted to
operate such motor vehicle within the city again. (1980 Code § 21-10)
3-8-10: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this chapter, or
any owner or licensee of any taxicab who allows or permits same to be driven or
operated by any person who does not have a current city driver's license, shall
be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to
penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. Each day upon which a violation continues shall be deemed a
separate offense. (1980 Code § 21-11; amd. 2002 Code)
CHAPTER 9
MEDICAL MARIJUANA
SECTION:
3-9-1: Definitions
3-9-2: General Requirements
3-9-3: Medical Marijuana Dispensary
3-9-4: Commercial Medical Marijuana Growing And/Or Processing Facilities
3-9-5: Medical Marijuana Wholesale And/Or Storage Facilities
3-9-6: Medical Marijuana Growing For Personal Use
3-9-7: Burning Requirements For Medical Marijuana
3-9-8: Penalty
3-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
COMMERCIAL MEDICAL MARIJUANA GROWING AND/OR PROCESSING FACILITIES: Any medical
marijuana growing or processing facility licensed by the State of Oklahoma to
grow or process medical marijuana in excess of twelve (12) plants. Growing
includes the cultivation, manufacturing, processing, packaging and distribution
of marijuana and marijuana products. Processing including, but not limited to:
drying, cleaning, curing, packaging and extraction of active ingredients to
create medical marijuana, medical marijuana products or concentrates.
MARIJUANA WHOLESALE AND/OR STORAGE FACILITY: Any wholesale or storage
establishment licensed by the State of Oklahoma and City of Drumright that
acquires, processes, stores, delivers, transfers, transports, supplies, sells
or dispenses marijuana or related supplies and educational materials to a
holder of a valid medical marijuana dispensary license.
MEDICAL MARIJUANA DISPENSARY: A retail medical marijuana establishment licensed
by the State of Oklahoma and the City of Drumright to sell or dispense medical
marijuana or medical marijuana products.
MEDICAL MARIJUANA GROWING FOR PERSONAL USE: Any individual licensed by the
State of Oklahoma and the City of Drumright to grow up to twelve (12) plants
within a single residence for personal medical use.
The City hereby adopts all other terms and definitions as established by State
law or Department of Health regulations. In the event of a conflict between any
definition contained herein, the definition promulgated by the State or the
Department of Health shall prevail. (Ord. 331, 10-9-2018)
3-9-2: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   State License Required: Applicants for any license contained herein
shall be required to possess a valid State of Oklahoma issued medical marijuana
license prior to making application for the City license.
   B.   Inspection: The license outlined in this chapter will be subject to
proper inspection by an authorized City inspector prior to issuance to ensure
compliance with all codes of the City.
   C.   Time Of Inspection: The property inspection will occur at a time
scheduled and approved by both the applicant and the City inspector.
   D.   Applicant Must Be Present During Inspection: The applicant will be
required to be present during the inspection.
   E.   Compliance With Building And Fire Codes: All structures, equipment, and
apparatuses shall comply with all Building and Fire Codes adopted by the State
of Oklahoma and the City of Drumright.
   F.   License Application: The Medical Marijuana Business License Application
shall be filled out and signed by the property and business owner and submitted
to the City Clerk prior to scheduling and inspection.
   G.   Payment Of License Fee: A nonrefundable license fee, as established
herein, shall be paid at the time the application is submitted.
   H.   License Fee Use: The license fee shall be set according to and used to
offset Municipal expenses covering costs relating to licensing, inspection,
administration and enforcement of this chapter.
   I.   Distance Requirements: For the distance requirements outlined in this
chapter, the distance described shall be computed by direct measurement in a
straight line from the nearest property line from the parcel of land on which
the use described herein is located and the nearest property line of the
building or unit in which the proposed retail marijuana establishment would be
located.
   J.   Location: All medical marijuana dispensary, commercial medical
marijuana growing and/or processing facilities and marijuana wholesale and/or
storage facility establishments shall be located within an entirely enclosed
and secure structure, as required by the Rules and Regulations of the
Department of Health, as may be amended from time to time.
   K.   Sales Tax: License holder shall remit all required State and City Sales
Taxes.
   L.   Prohibited Activities: It is the intent of the City of Drumright that
nothing in this chapter be construed to:
      1.   Allow persons to engage in conduct that endangers the health, safety
or welfare of the citizens of the City of Drumright, or causes a public
nuisance;
      2.   Allow the use of marijuana for non-medical purposes; or
      3.   Allow any activity that is otherwise illegal and not permitted by
State law.
   M.   Additional Regulations:
      1.   Noxious Odor: The smell of noxious odor emitted from smoking or
consumption of medical marijuana by a person possessing a valid State issued
marijuana license shall constitute a public nuisance.
      2.   Smoking On City Property Prohibited: Smoking and vaping marijuana
shall be prohibited on all City property including vehicles, buildings, parks
or other facilities.
      3.   Revocation Or Suspension Of Municipal Issued Marijuana License;
Hearing:
         a.   The City Manager or designee shall revoke or suspend a license
issued under this section on any of the following grounds:
            (1)   The license was procured by fraudulent conduct or false
statement of a material fact or a fact concerning the applicant was not
disclosed at the time of his application, and such fact would have constituted
just cause for refusal to issue the license; and
            (2)   Violation of City ordinance, State law or Department of
Health regulation covering medical marijuana.
         b.   Prior to suspension or revocation the permittee shall be given
notice of the proposed action to be taken and shall have an opportunity to be
heard before the City Manager. If any employee has been designated by the City
Manager, such employee shall make a report to the City Manager together with a
recommendation as to whether the license should be suspended or revoked.
      4.   Compliance: Any person or entity licensed by the City of Drumright
shall comply with all State law and Department of Health rules and regulations,
as be amended from time to time.
      5.   License Revocation: Revocation of the State issued license shall
result in immediate revocation of the City issued license. (Ord. 331, 10-9-
2018)
      6.   Variances: Applicants may request variances relating to location by
following the procedures for variances set forth by the City of Drumright in
title 10, chapter 3 of this Code. (Ord. 333, 6-10-2019)
3-9-3: MEDICAL MARIJUANA DISPENSARY:
Medical marijuana dispensaries are hereby allowed in the Municipal boundaries
of Drumright, Oklahoma on compliance with section
3-9-2 of this chapter, issuance of retail medical marijuana dispensary business
license and the following additional provisions:
   A.   Location: A medical marijuana dispensary license will not be granted to
any applicant where the proposed location would be located within five hundred
feet (500') of any of the following locations:
      1.   A private or public pre-school, elementary, secondary, vocational or
trade school, college or university;
      2.   A library or museum;
      3.   Public playground;
      4.   A childcare center;
      5.   Place of worship or religious assembly;
      6.   A public park, pool, or recreation facility;
      7.   A juvenile or adult half-way house, correctional facility or
substance abuse rehabilitation or treatment center;
      8.   A residentially zoned district; or
      9.   Another medical marijuana or retail marijuana establishment.
   B.   Conditions Of Operation:
      1.   Buildings where medical marijuana is stored or dispensed must be
equipped with ventilation-air filtration systems so that no odors are
detectable off premises;
      2.   The retail establishment must maintain a valid Sales Tax permit
issued by the State of Oklahoma;
      3.   No on premises use of marijuana or its derivatives shall be allowed;
      4.   Any violations of this section will result in the revocation of the
retail medical marijuana business license.
   C.   License And Renewal Fees: There shall be a business license fee and an
annual renewal fee in the amount of one thousand two hundred fifty dollars
($1,250.00). The annual business license will expire on June 30th and shall be
renewed prior to July 1st each year. Failure to renew will result in a penalty
of fifty percent (50%) of the annual fee and shall require re-inspection. (Ord.
331, 10-9-2018)
3-9-4: COMMERCIAL MEDICAL MARIJUANA GROWING AND/OR PROCESSING FACILITIES:
Commercial medical marijuana growing and/or processing facilities are hereby
allowed within the Municipal boundaries of Drumright, Oklahoma upon compliance
of section
3-9-2 of this chapter, issuance of a commercial medical marijuana growing and/
or facility license and the following additional provisions:
   A.   Location: A commercial medical marijuana growing and/or processing
facility permit will not be granted to any applicant where the approved
location would be within one thousand feet (1,000.00') of any of the following
locations:
      1.   Private or public pre-school, elementary, secondary, vocational or
trade school, college or university;
      2.   A library or museum;
      3.   Public playground;
      4.   A childcare center;
      5.   Place of worship or religious assembly;
      6.   A public park, pool, or recreation facility;
      7.   A juvenile or adult half-way house, correctional facility or
substance abuse rehabilitation or treatment center;
      8.   A residentially zoned district; or
      9.   Another medical marijuana or retail marijuana establishment.
   B.   Conditions Of Operation:
      1.   Facilities shall be secure with limited access. The secure area must
be locked at all times. A key or access code shall be provided to all emergency
services (fire, police and EMS). Changing the code or key shall not be allowed
without proper notification to all emergency services.
      2.   The establishment must maintain a valid tax permit issued by the
State of Oklahoma.
      3.   The facility must be constructed in such a manner that the growing
of the medical marijuana plants cannot be seen by the public from the public
right-of-way.
      4.   The growing area, including any lighting, plumbing or electrical
components used shall comply with all Building and Fire Codes issued by the
State of Oklahoma and the City of Drumright.
      5.   The growing area must be properly ventilated so as not to create
humidity, mold or other related problems.
      6.   Growing medical marijuana shall not be conducted in a manner that
constitutes a public nuisance. A public nuisance may be deemed to exist if
growing marijuana produces light, glare, heat, noise, odor or vibration that is
detrimental to public health, safety or welfare or interferes with the
reasonable enjoyment of life and property.
   C.   License And Renewal Fees: There shall be a business license fee and an
annual renewal fee in the amount of one thousand two hundred fifty dollars
($1,250.00). The annual business license will expire on June 30th and shall be
renewed prior to July 1st each year. Failure to renew will result in a penalty
of fifty percent (50%) of the annual fee and shall require re-inspection. (Ord.
331, 10-9-2018)
3-9-5: MEDICAL MARIJUANA WHOLESALE AND/OR STORAGE FACILITIES:
Medical marijuana wholesale and/or storage facilities are hereby allowed within
the Municipal boundaries of Drumright, Oklahoma upon compliance of section
3-9-2 of this chapter, issuance of a medical marijuana wholesale and/or storage
facility license and the following additional requirements:
   A.   Location: Wholesale marijuana facilities permit will not be granted to
any applicants where the proposed location is located outside commercially
zoned areas of the City limits of Drumright.
   B.   Conditions Of Operation:
      1.   Facilities shall be secure with limited access. The secure area must
be locked at all times. A key or access code shall be provided to all emergency
services (fire, police and EMS). Changing the code or key shall not be allowed
without proper notification to all emergency services.
      2.   Buildings where medical marijuana is stored or dispensed must be
equipped with ventilation/air filtration systems so that no odors are
detectable off premises.
      3.   The establishment must maintain a valid tax permit issued by the
State of Oklahoma.
   C.   License And Renewal Fees: There shall be a business license fee and an
annual renewal fee in the amount of one thousand two hundred fifty dollars
($1,250.00). The annual business license will expire on June 30th and shall be
renewed prior to July 1st each year. Failure to renew will result in a penalty
of fifty percent (50%) of the annual fee and shall require re-inspection. (Ord.
331, 10-9-2018)
3-9-6: MEDICAL MARIJUANA GROWING FOR PERSONAL USE:
Medical marijuana growing for personal use is hereby allowed in the Municipal
boundaries of Drumright, Oklahoma on compliance with section
3-9-2 of this chapter, issuance of medical marijuana growing for personal use
license and the following additional provisions:
   A.   Any license issued to an individual for the growing of medical
marijuana for personal use will be for the growing of medical marijuana at the
individual's primary residence. The City Clerk shall be notified immediately
upon any change of address of the licensee.
   B.   Any access or entry point to residential facilities used for medical
marijuana cultivation for personal medical use must be secured by lock and key
or equivalent at all times except when the residential facility is actively
being supervised in person by the permit holder.
   C.   Growing medical marijuana shall not be visible from the public right-
of-way.
   D.   The growing area including any lighting, plumbing or electrical
components used shall comply with Municipal Building and Fire Codes. The
growing area must be properly ventilated so as not to create humidity, mold or
other related problems. Lighting shall not exceed one thousand (1,000) watts
per light. The use of gas products (CO2, butane, etc.) or CO2 and ozone
generators in the growing area is prohibited.
   E.   Growing medical marijuana shall not be conducted in a manner that
constitutes a public nuisance. A public nuisance may be deemed to exist if
growing marijuana produces light, glare, heat, noise, odor or vibration that is
detrimental to public health, safety or welfare or interferes with the
reasonable enjoyment of life and property.
   F.   The primary use of the residential property in which medical marijuana
is grown shall remain at all times a residence, with legal and functional
cooking, eating, sleeping and sanitation/bathing facilities with proper ingress
and egress. No room shall be used for growing marijuana where such cultivation
will impair or prevent the primary uses of cooking, eating, sleeping or
sanitation/bathing.
   G.   If the residence is rented, consent of the property owner shall be
obtained prior to any cultivation commencing. This consent must be evidenced by
a signed and notarized statement from the property owner permitting the growth
of marijuana in a residence. A copy of this signed and notarized consent must
be provided to the Drumright City Clerk.
   H.   An individual licensed to grow marijuana for personal use shall have a
license issued by the State of Oklahoma authorizing the use of medical
marijuana. Said license shall be made available to any authorized City employee
upon request.
   I.   There shall be a license fee and an annual renewal fee in the amount of
fifty dollars ($50.00). The annual license will expire on June 30th and shall
be renewed prior to July 1st each year. Failure to renew will result in a
penalty of fifty percent (50%) of the annual fee and shall require re-
inspection. (Ord. 331, 10-9-2018)
3-9-7: BURNING REQUIREMENTS FOR MEDICAL MARIJUANA:
   A.   All medical marijuana plant material and waste generated during the
cultivation, production, processing, handling, and testing of medical marijuana
and medical marijuana products must be stored, managed, and disposed of in
accordance with these rules, the Oklahoma Medical Marijuana Waste Management
Act, 63 O.S. § 427a et seq., and any other applicable Oklahoma statutes and
rules, except that medical marijuana waste shall not be subject to the
provisions of the Uniform Controlled Dangerous Substances Act, 63 O.S. § 2-101
et seq.
   B.   Licensees may dispose of root balls, stems, fan leaves, seeds, and the
mature stalks or fiber produced from such stalks at the licensed premises by
open burning, incineration, burying, mulching, composting or any other
technique approved by the Department of Environmental Quality.
   C.   Burning may not be done within five hundred feet (500') of occupied
structures.
   D.   Mobile incinerators are not permitted unless specifically approved by
DEQ. (Ord. 335, 2-10-2020)
3-9-8: PENALTY:
   A.   In addition to license revocation or suspension, a violation of any of
the provisions contained in this chapter shall also be deemed an offense and
punishable, as provided in this Code.
   B.   A violation of the provisions of section
3-9-7 shall also be deemed an offense and punishable, as provided in City Code,
by a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500) a day. The city may also take
civil action as deemed appropriate. (Ord. 331, 10-9-2018; amd. Ord. 335, 2-10-
2020)
TITLE 4
PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY
CHAPTER 1
HEALTH REGULATIONS
SECTION:
4-1-1: Health Officer
4-1-2: Health Inspector
4-1-3: City Inspections; Protect Public Health
4-1-4: Contagious Diseases
4-1-5: Penalty
4-1-1: HEALTH OFFICER:
   A.   Appointment; County Director Serve:
      1.   The city commission may at any time by resolution direct the city
manager to appoint a health officer and may direct duties, compensations and
term of office by such resolution.
      2.   The director of the Creek County health department may serve in the
capacity of health officer. (1980 Code § 11-1)
   B.   Duties: The health officer shall have general supervision of the
enforcement of the health ordinances of the city and state within the limits of
the city and five (5) miles beyond the boundary of the city. He shall give and
perform any and all duties as are now or may hereafter be imposed upon him by
ordinance, law or the orders of the board of commissioners or the city manager.
(1980 Code § 11-2)
   C.   Directions: The orders of the health officer and all notices
promulgated by him shall be on forms provided for that purpose and shall be
served by the chief of police or other person deputized by the said health
officer. (1980 Code § 11-7)
4-1-2: HEALTH INSPECTOR:
   A.   Health Officer Serve As Inspector: The health officer shall be ex
officio health inspector and exercise all powers and duties imposed upon said
officer by the city ordinances. (1980 Code § 11-3)
   B.   Duties: It shall be the duty of the health inspector to examine into
and consider all measures necessary and prescribe reasonable rules and
regulations for the preservation of the public health of the city and to see
that all ordinances and regulations in relation thereto are observed. (1980
Code § 11-4)
4-1-3: CITY INSPECTIONS; PROTECT PUBLIC HEALTH:
   A.   Inspections Of City: It shall be the duty of the health inspector to
make or cause to be made an inspection of the city as often as he may deem
necessary and at such times as may be ordered by the board of commissioners or
city manager for the purpose of examining the sanitary conditions of the city.
   B.   Right Of Entry: The health inspector or any person acting under his
direction shall have authority to enter into and examine, at any time, all
buildings, places and premises for the purpose of ascertaining the conditions
thereof, as far as the public health may be affected thereby, and as necessary
in the performance of any city devolving on said officer. (1980 Code § 11-6)
4-1-4: CONTAGIOUS DISEASES:
   A.   Physicians; Duties:
      1.   It shall be the duty of every physician practicing within the city
to make a report to the health officer, upon forms prescribed and furnished by
the state board of health, of all cases of infectious and contagious disease,
as soon as discovered by him or coming to his knowledge. Any failure upon the
part of any physician to report within twenty four (24) hours said disease as
herein provided, shall be an offense and, upon conviction, shall be punished
accordingly.
      2.   It shall be the duty of the physician in charge of such cases to
report to the same officer when it is time to fumigate such premises and said
fumigation shall be done by the owner or occupant under the direction of the
health officer or person authorized by him. (1980 Code § 11-8)
      3.   Every practicing physician in the city shall report within twenty
four (24) hours thereafter, the death of any person dying of any pestilential,
contagious or infectious disease to the health officer and such report shall
state the specific nature and type of the disease. (1980 Code § 11-9)
   B.   Health Certificate: It shall be an offense for any person having or
having had any contagious or infectious disease to go about in any public place
until he shall have obtained from the health officer, a certificate stating
that he has fully recovered from such disease, that the premises wherein he was
sick has been properly fumigated, and that he cannot impart such disease to
others; or to neglect or refuse to change and purify his wearing apparel before
going into any public place; or to so conduct himself as to cause the spreading
of the disease. (1980 Code § 11-10)
   C.   Destroying Health Notices: It shall be an offense for any person to
tear down, destroy, mutilate or deface any sign or notice placed by order of
the health officer. It shall be an offense to cover up, conceal or render
useless any such notice or to place any obstruction in front of the same. (1980
Code § 11-11)
   D.   Disease Control Authority:
      1.   The health officer shall have power, in case of public necessity, to
require all citizens of the city to be vaccinated at such times and places as
he shall direct and it shall be the duty of the said health officer to direct
that all citizens be vaccinated whenever in his opinion it becomes necessary
for the preservation of the public health.
      2.   Notice therefor shall be sufficient to all when given by
proclamation, published in one issue of a newspaper having a general
circulation in the city or by posting in five (5) public places within the city
limits. The expenses for such vaccination shall be a charge against the city.
(1980 Code § 11-12)
4-1-5: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any provision of this
chapter, by doing an act prohibited or declared to be unlawful thereby, or
declared to be an offense or misdemeanor or nuisance thereby, or who shall fail
to do any act when such provision declares such failure to be unlawful or to be
an offense or misdemeanor, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon
conviction thereof, shall be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. Each day upon which any such violation continues shall
constitute a separate offense. (1980 Code § 11-34; amd. 2002 Code)
CHAPTER 2
NUISANCES
SECTION:
4-2-1: Nuisance Defined, Generally
4-2-2: Responsibility; Nuisance Unlawful
4-2-3: Time Does Not Legalize
4-2-4: Remedies
4-2-5: Power To Define And Summarily Abate Nuisances
4-2-6: Certain Public Nuisances Defined
4-2-7: Health Nuisances; Abatement
4-2-8: Throwing Handbills, Advertisements
4-2-9: Summary Abatement Of Nuisances
4-2-10: Abatement By Suit In District Court
4-2-11: Procedure Cumulative
4-2-12: Penalty
4-2-1: NUISANCE DEFINED, GENERALLY:
   A.   Nuisance: A "nuisance" is unlawfully doing an act, or omitting to
perform a duty, or is any thing or condition, which either:
      1.   Annoys, injures, or endangers the comfort, repose, health, or safety
of others;
      2.   Offends decency;
      3.   Unlawfully interferes with, obstructs, or tends to obstruct, or
renders dangerous for passage, any lake or navigable river, stream, canal or
basin, or any public park, square, street, or other public property; or
      4.   In any way renders other persons insecure in life or in the use of
property.
   B.   Public Nuisance: A "public nuisance" is one which affects at the same
time an entire community or neighborhood or any considerable number of persons,
although the extent of the annoyance or damage inflicted upon the individuals
may be unequal.
   C.   Private Nuisance: Every nuisance not included in subsection B of this
section is a private nuisance. (1980 Code § 13-1)
4-2-2: RESPONSIBILITY; NUISANCE UNLAWFUL:
   A.   Persons Responsible: Every successive owner of property who neglects to
abate a continuing nuisance upon or in the use of such property, created by a
former owner, is liable therefor in the same manner as the one who first
created it. (1980 Code § 13-2)
   B.   Nuisance Unlawful: It is unlawful for any person (owner, lessee, or
other) to create or maintain a nuisance within the city, or to permit a
nuisance to remain on premises under his control within the city. (1980 Code §
13-10)
4-2-3: TIME DOES NOT LEGALIZE:
No lapse of time can legalize a public nuisance amounting to an actual
obstruction of public right. (1980 Code § 13-3)
4-2-4: REMEDIES:
   A.   Public Nuisances: The remedies against a public nuisance are:
      1.   Prosecution on complaint before the municipal court.
      2.   Prosecution on information or indictment before another appropriate
court.
      3.   Civil action.
      4.   Abatement:
         a.   By person injured, as provided in 50 Oklahoma Statutes section
12.
         b.   By the city, in accordance with law or ordinance. (1980 Code §
13-4)
   B.   Private Nuisances: The remedies against a private nuisance are:
      1.   Civil action.
      2.   Abatement:
         a.   By person injured, as provided in 50 Oklahoma Statutes sections
14 and 15.
         b.   By the city, in accordance with law or ordinance. (1980 Code §
13-5)
4-2-5: POWER TO DEFINE AND SUMMARILY ABATE NUISANCES:
As provided in 50 Oklahoma Statutes section 16, the city has power to determine
what is and what shall constitute a nuisance within its corporate limits and,
for the protection of the public health, the public parks, and the public water
supply, outside of its corporate limits. Whenever it is practical to do so, the
city has power summarily to abate any such nuisance after notice to the owner
and an opportunity for him to be heard, if this can be done. (1980 Code § 13-6)
4-2-6: CERTAIN PUBLIC NUISANCES DEFINED:
   A.   Nuisances Enumerated: In addition to other public nuisances declared by
other sections of this code or law, the following are hereby declared to be
public nuisances:
      1.   Unwholesome Food: The sale, or offering for sale, of unwholesome
food or drink; or the keeping of a place where such sales or offerings are
made.
      2.   Liquor: The sale, offering for sale, or furnishing of intoxicating
liquor in violation of the state law or ordinances of the city; or the keeping
of a place where intoxicating liquor is sold, offered for sale, or furnished in
violation of the state law or ordinances of the city.
      3.   Obscene Literature: The exposure, display, sale, or distribution of
obscene pictures, books, pamphlets, magazines, papers, documents, or objects;
or the keeping of a place where such are exposed, displayed, sold, or
distributed.
      4.   Gambling: The keeping of a place where persons gamble, whether by
cards, slot machines, punchboards, or otherwise.
      5.   House Of Prostitution: The keeping of a place where prostitution,
illicit sexual intercourse, or other immoral acts are practiced.
      6.   Place Where Unlawful Activities Occur: The keeping of a place where
activities in violation of state law or ordinance are practiced or carried on.
      7.   Illegal Dances: The conduct or holding of public dances in violation
of the ordinances of the city; or the keeping of a place where such dances are
held.
      8.   Exposing Person With Contagious Disease: The public exposure of a
person having a contagious disease.
      9.   Loud Noises By Persons Or Animals: The continued making of loud or
unusual noises which annoy persons of ordinary sensibilities; or the keeping of
an animal which makes such noise 1 .
      10.   Interference With Radio Or Television Reception: The operation or
use of any electrical apparatus or machine which materially and unduly
interferes with radio or television reception by others.
      11.   Crowds Obstructing Traffic: Any use of a street or sidewalk or a
place adjacent thereto which causes crowds of people to gather so as to
obstruct traffic on such street or sidewalk, or which otherwise obstructs
traffic thereon, except as may be authorized by law or ordinances.
      12.   Liquid Or Snow Falling From Building: Permitting water or other
liquid to flow or fall, or ice or snow to fall, from any building or structure
upon any street or sidewalk.
      13.   Stagnant Water: All wells, pools, cisterns, bodies, or containers
of water in which mosquitoes breed or are likely to breed, or which are so
constructed, formed, conditioned, or situated as to endanger the public safety.
      14.   Weeds And Refuse: Rank weeds or grass, carcasses, accumulations of
manure, refuse, or other things, which are, or are likely to be, breeding
places for flies, mosquitoes, vermin, or disease germs; and the premises on
which such exist.
      15.   Dangerous Building: Any building or structure which is dangerous to
the public health or safety because of damage, decay, or other condition, or
